17656.text: §¶The vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzzi′ah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezeki′ah, kings of Judah.

17657.text: §¶Hear, O heavens, and give ear, O earth;/_for the Lord has spoken:/“Sons have I reared and brought up,/_but they have rebelled against me.

17658.text: /The ox knows its owner,/_and the ass its master’s crib;/but Israel does not know,/_my people does not understand.”

17659.text: ¶Ah, sinful nation,/_a people laden with iniquity,/offspring of evildoers,/_sons who deal corruptly!/They have forsaken the Lord,/_they have despised the Holy One of Israel,/_they are utterly estranged.

17660.text: ¶Why will you still be smitten,/_that you continue to rebel?/The whole head is sick,/_and the whole heart faint.

17661.text: /From the sole of the foot even to the head,/_there is no soundness in it,/but bruises and sores/_and bleeding wounds;/they are not pressed out, or bound up,/_or softened with oil.

17662.text: ¶Your country lies desolate,/_your cities are burned with fire;/in your very presence/_aliens devour your land;/_it is desolate, as overthrown by aliens.

17663.text: /And the daughter of Zion is left/_like a booth in a vineyard,/like a lodge in a cucumber field,/_like a besieged city.

17664.text: ¶If the Lord of hosts/_had not left us a few survivors,/we should have been like Sodom,/_and become like Gomor′rah.

17665.text: ¶Hear the word of the Lord,/_you rulers of Sodom!/Give ear to the teaching of our God,/_you people of Gomor′rah!

17666.text: /“What to me is the multitude of your sacrifices?/_says the Lord;/I have had enough of burnt offerings of rams/_and the fat of fed beasts;/I do not delight in the blood of bulls,/_or of lambs, or of he‑goats.

17667.text: ¶“When you come to appear before me,/_who requires of you/_this trampling of my courts?

17668.text: /Bring no more vain offerings;/_incense is an abomination to me./New moon and sabbath and the calling of assemblies—/_I cannot endure iniquity and solemn assembly.

17669.text: /Your new moons and your appointed feasts/_my soul hates;/they have become a burden to me,/_I am weary of bearing them.

17670.text: /When you spread forth your hands,/_I will hide my eyes from you;/even though you make many prayers,/_I will not listen;/_your hands are full of blood.

17671.text: /Wash yourselves; make yourselves clean;/_remove the evil of your doings/_from before my eyes;/cease to do evil,

17672.text: /_learn to do good;/seek justice,/_correct oppression;/defend the fatherless,/_plead for the widow.

17673.text: ¶“Come now, let us reason together,/_says the Lord:/though your sins are like scarlet,/_they shall be as white as snow;/though they are red like crimson,/_they shall become like wool.

17674.text: /If you are willing and obedient,/_you shall eat the good of the land;

17675.text: /but if you refuse and rebel,/_you shall be devoured by the sword;/_for the mouth of the Lord has spoken.”

17676.text: §¶How the faithful city/_has become a harlot,/_she that was full of justice!/Righteousness lodged in her,/_but now murderers.

17677.text: /Your silver has become dross,/_your wine mixed with water.

17678.text: /Your princes are rebels/_and companions of thieves./Every one loves a bribe/_and runs after gifts./They do not defend the fatherless,/_and the widow’s cause does not come to them.

17679.text: ¶Therefore the Lord says,/_the Lord of hosts,/_the Mighty One of Israel:/“Ah, I will vent my wrath on my enemies,/_and avenge myself on my foes.

17680.text: /I will turn my hand against you/_and will smelt away your dross as with lye/_and remove all your alloy.

17681.text: /And I will restore your judges as at the first,/_and your counselors as at the beginning./Afterward you shall be called the city of righteousness,/_the faithful city.”

17682.text: ¶Zion shall be redeemed by justice,/_and those in her who repent, by righteousness.

17683.text: /But rebels and sinners shall be destroyed together,/_and those who forsake the Lord shall be consumed.

17684.text: /For you shall be ashamed of the oaks/_in which you delighted;/and you shall blush for the gardens/_which you have chosen.

17685.text: /For you shall be like an oak/_whose leaf withers,/_and like a garden without water.

17686.text: /And the strong shall become tow,/_and his work a spark,/and both of them shall burn together,/_with none to quench them.

17687.text: §¶The word which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.

17688.text: ¶It shall come to pass in the latter days/_that the mountain of the house of the Lord/shall be established as the highest of the mountains,/_and shall be raised above the hills;/and all the nations shall flow to it,

17689.text: /_and many peoples shall come, and say:/“Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord,/_to the house of the God of Jacob;/that he may teach us his ways/_and that we may walk in his paths.”/For out of Zion shall go forth the law,/_and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.

17690.text: /He shall judge between the nations,/_and shall decide for many peoples;/and they shall beat their swords into plowshares,/_and their spears into pruning hooks;/nation shall not lift up sword against nation,/_neither shall they learn war any more.

17691.text: §¶O house of Jacob,/_come, let us walk/_in the light of the Lord.

17692.text: ¶For thou hast rejected thy people,/_the house of Jacob,/because they are full of diviners from the east/_and of soothsayers like the Philistines,/_and they strike hands with foreigners.

17693.text: /Their land is filled with silver and gold,/_and there is no end to their treasures;/their land is filled with horses,/_and there is no end to their chariots.

17694.text: /Their land is filled with idols;/_they bow down to the work of their hands,/_to what their own fingers have made.

17695.text: /So man is humbled,/_and men are brought low—/_forgive them not!

17696.text: /Enter into the rock,/_and hide in the dust/from before the terror of the Lord,/_and from the glory of his majesty.

17697.text: /The haughty looks of man shall be brought low,/_and the pride of men shall be humbled;/and the Lord alone will be exalted/_in that day.

17698.text: ¶For the Lord of hosts has a day/_against all that is proud and lofty,/_against all that is lifted up and high;

17699.text: /against all the cedars of Lebanon,/_lofty and lifted up;/_and against all the oaks of Bashan;

17700.text: /against all the high mountains,/_and against all the lofty hills;

17701.text: /against every high tower,/_and against every fortified wall;

17702.text: /against all the ships of Tarshish,/_and against all the beautiful craft.

17703.text: /And the haughtiness of man shall be humbled,/_and the pride of men shall be brought low;/_and the Lord alone will be exalted in that day.

17704.text: /And the idols shall utterly pass away.

17705.text: /And men shall enter the caves of the rocks/_and the holes of the ground,/from before the terror of the Lord,/_and from the glory of his majesty,/_when he rises to terrify the earth.

17706.text: ¶In that day men will cast forth/_their idols of silver and their idols of gold,/which they made for themselves to worship,/_to the moles and to the bats,

17707.text: /to enter the caverns of the rocks/_and the clefts of the cliffs,/from before the terror of the Lord,/_and from the glory of his majesty,/_when he rises to terrify the earth.

17708.text: /Turn away from man/_in whose nostrils is breath,/_for of what account is he?

17709.text: ¶For, behold, the Lord, the Lord of hosts,/_is taking away from Jerusalem and from Judah/stay and staff,/_the whole stay of bread,/_and the whole stay of water;

17710.text: /the mighty man and the soldier,/_the judge and the prophet,/_the diviner and the elder,

17711.text: /the captain of fifty/_and the man of rank,/the counselor and the skilful magician/_and the expert in charms.

17712.text: /And I will make boys their princes,/_and babes shall rule over them.

17713.text: /And the people will oppress one another,/_every man his fellow/_and every man his neighbor;/the youth will be insolent to the elder,/_and the base fellow to the honorable.

17714.text: ¶When a man takes hold of his brother/_in the house of his father, saying:/“You have a mantle;/_you shall be our leader,/and this heap of ruins/_shall be under your rule”;

17715.text: /in that day he will speak out, saying:/“I will not be a healer;/_in my house there is neither bread nor mantle;/you shall not make me/_leader of the people.”

17716.text: /For Jerusalem has stumbled,/_and Judah has fallen;/because their speech and their deeds are against the Lord,/_defying his glorious presence.

17717.text: ¶Their partiality witnesses against them;/_they proclaim their sin like Sodom,/_they do not hide it./Woe to them!/_For they have brought evil upon themselves.

17718.text: /Tell the righteous that it shall be well with them,/_for they shall eat the fruit of their deeds.

17719.text: /Woe to the wicked! It shall be ill with him,/_for what his hands have done shall be done to him.

17720.text: /My people—children are their oppressors,/_and women rule over them./O my people, your leaders mislead you,/_and confuse the course of your paths.

17721.text: ¶The Lord has taken his place to contend,/_he stands to judge his people.

17722.text: /The Lord enters into judgment/_with the elders and princes of his people:/“It is you who have devoured the vineyard,/_the spoil of the poor is in your houses.

17723.text: /What do you mean by crushing my people,/_by grinding the face of the poor?”/_says the Lord God of hosts.

17724.text: ¶The Lord said:/Because the daughters of Zion are haughty/_and walk with outstretched necks,/_glancing wantonly with their eyes,/mincing along as they go,/_tinkling with their feet;

17725.text: /the Lord will smite with a scab/_the heads of the daughters of Zion,/_and the Lord will lay bare their secret parts.

17726.text: ¶In that day the Lord will take away the finery of the anklets, the headbands, and the crescents;

17727.text: the pendants, the bracelets, and the scarfs;

17728.text: the headdresses, the armlets, the sashes, the perfume boxes, and the amulets;

17729.text: the signet rings and nose rings;

17730.text: the festal robes, the mantles, the cloaks, and the handbags;

17731.text: the garments of gauze, the linen garments, the turbans, and the veils.

17732.text: ¶Instead of perfume there will be rottenness;/_and instead of a girdle, a rope;/and instead of well‑set hair, baldness;/_and instead of a rich robe, a girding of sackcloth;/_instead of beauty, shame.

17733.text: /Your men shall fall by the sword/_and your mighty men in battle.

17734.text: /And her gates shall lament and mourn;/_ravaged, she shall sit upon the ground.

17735.text: ¶And seven women shall take hold of one man in that day, saying, “We will eat our own bread and wear our own clothes, only let us be called by your name; take away our reproach.”

17736.text: §¶In that day the branch of the Lord shall be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the land shall be the pride and glory of the survivors of Israel.

17737.text: And he who is left in Zion and remains in Jerusalem will be called holy, every one who has been recorded for life in Jerusalem,

17738.text: when the Lord shall have washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion and cleansed the bloodstains of Jerusalem from its midst by a spirit of judgment and by a spirit of burning.

17739.text: Then the Lord will create over the whole site of Mount Zion and over her assemblies a cloud by day, and smoke and the shining of a flaming fire by night; for over all the glory there will be a canopy and a pavilion.

17740.text: It will be for a shade by day from the heat, and for a refuge and a shelter from the storm and rain.

17741.text: §¶Let me sing for my beloved/_a love song concerning his vineyard:/My beloved had a vineyard/_on a very fertile hill.

17742.text: /He digged it and cleared it of stones,/_and planted it with choice vines;/he built a watchtower in the midst of it,/_and hewed out a wine vat in it;/and he looked for it to yield grapes,/_but it yielded wild grapes.

17743.text: ¶And now, O inhabitants of Jerusalem/_and men of Judah,/judge, I pray you, between me/_and my vineyard.

17744.text: /What more was there to do for my vineyard,/_that I have not done in it?/When I looked for it to yield grapes,/_why did it yield wild grapes?

17745.text: ¶And now I will tell you/_what I will do to my vineyard./I will remove its hedge,/_and it shall be devoured;/I will break down its wall,/_and it shall be trampled down.

17746.text: /I will make it a waste;/_it shall not be pruned or hoed,/_and briers and thorns shall grow up;/I will also command the clouds/_that they rain no rain upon it.

17747.text: ¶For the vineyard of the Lord of hosts/_is the house of Israel,/and the men of Judah/_are his pleasant planting;/and he looked for justice,/_but behold, bloodshed;/for righteousness,/_but behold, a cry!

17748.text: §¶Woe to those who join house to house,/_who add field to field,/until there is no more room,/_and you are made to dwell alone/_in the midst of the land.

17749.text: /The Lord of hosts has sworn in my hearing:/“Surely many houses shall be desolate,/_large and beautiful houses, without inhabitant.

17750.text: /For ten acres of vineyard shall yield but one bath,/_and a homer of seed shall yield but an ephah.”

17751.text: ¶Woe to those who rise early in the morning,/_that they may run after strong drink,/who tarry late into the evening/_till wine inflames them!

17752.text: /They have lyre and harp,/_timbrel and flute and wine at their feasts;/but they do not regard the deeds of the Lord,/_or see the work of his hands.

17753.text: ¶Therefore my people go into exile/_for want of knowledge;/their honored men are dying of hunger,/_and their multitude is parched with thirst.

17754.text: /Therefore Sheol has enlarged its appetite/_and opened its mouth beyond measure,/and the nobility of Jerusalem and her multitude go down,/_her throng and he who exults in her.

17755.text: /Man is bowed down, and men are brought low,/_and the eyes of the haughty are humbled.

17756.text: /But the Lord of hosts is exalted in justice,/_and the Holy God shows himself holy in righteousness.

17757.text: /Then shall the lambs graze as in their pasture,/_fatlings and kids shall feed among the ruins.

17758.text: ¶Woe to those who draw iniquity with cords of falsehood,/_who draw sin as with cart ropes,

17759.text: /who say: “Let him make haste,/_let him speed his work/_that we may see it;/let the purpose of the Holy One of Israel draw near,/_and let it come, that we may know it!”

17760.text: /Woe to those who call evil good/_and good evil,/who put darkness for light/_and light for darkness,/who put bitter for sweet/_and sweet for bitter!

17761.text: /Woe to those who are wise in their own eyes,/_and shrewd in their own sight!

17762.text: /Woe to those who are heroes at drinking wine,/_and valiant men in mixing strong drink,

17763.text: /who acquit the guilty for a bribe,/_and deprive the innocent of his right!

17764.text: §¶Therefore, as the tongue of fire devours the stubble,/_and as dry grass sinks down in the flame,/so their root will be as rottenness,/_and their blossom go up like dust;/for they have rejected the law of the Lord of hosts,/_and have despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.

17765.text: /Therefore the anger of the Lord was kindled against his people,/_and he stretched out his hand against them and smote them,/_and the mountains quaked;/and their corpses were as refuse/_in the midst of the streets./For all this his anger is not turned away/_and his hand is stretched out still.

17766.text: ¶He will raise a signal for a nation afar off,/_and whistle for it from the ends of the earth;/and lo, swiftly, speedily it comes!

17767.text: /None is weary, none stumbles,/_none slumbers or sleeps,/not a waistcloth is loose,/_not a sandal‑thong broken;

17768.text: /their arrows are sharp,/_all their bows bent,/their horses’ hoofs seem like flint,/_and their wheels like the whirlwind.

17769.text: /Their roaring is like a lion,/_like young lions they roar;/they growl and seize their prey,/_they carry it off, and none can rescue.

17770.text: /They will growl over it on that day,/_like the roaring of the sea./And if one look to the land,/_behold, darkness and distress;/and the light is darkened by its clouds.

17771.text: §¶In the year that King Uzzi′ah died I saw the Lord sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up; and his train filled the temple.

17772.text: Above him stood the seraphim; each had six wings: with two he covered his face, and with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew.

17773.text: And one called to another and said:¶▼“Holy, holy, holy is the Lord of hosts;/the whole earth is full of his glory.”

17774.text: ¶And the foundations of the thresholds shook at the voice of him who called, and the house was filled with smoke.

17775.text: And I said: “Woe is me! For I am lost; for I am a man of unclean lips, and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips; for my eyes have seen the King, the Lord of hosts!”

17776.text: ¶Then flew one of the seraphim to me, having in his hand a burning coal which he had taken with tongs from the altar.

17777.text: And he touched my mouth, and said: “Behold, this has touched your lips; your guilt is taken away, and your sin forgiven.”

17778.text: And I heard the voice of the Lord saying, “Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?” Then I said, “Here am I! Send me.”

17779.text: And he said, “Go, and say to this people:¶▼‘Hear and hear, but do not understand;/see and see, but do not perceive.’

17780.text: /Make the heart of this people fat,/_and their ears heavy,/_and shut their eyes;/lest they see with their eyes,/_and hear with their ears,/and understand with their hearts,/_and turn and be healed.”

17781.text: ¶Then I said, “How long, O Lord?”¶And he said:¶▼“Until cities lie waste/_without inhabitant,/and houses without men,/_and the land is utterly desolate,

17782.text: /and the Lord removes men far away,/_and the forsaken places are many in the midst of the land.

17783.text: /And though a tenth remain in it,/_it will be burned again,/like a terebinth or an oak,/_whose stump remains standing/_when it is felled.”/The holy seed is its stump.

17784.text: §¶In the days of Ahaz the son of Jotham, son of Uzzi′ah, king of Judah, Rezin the king of Syria and Pekah the son of Remali′ah the king of Israel came up to Jerusalem to wage war against it, but they could not conquer it.

17785.text: When the house of David was told, “Syria is in league with E′phraim,” his heart and the heart of his people shook as the trees of the forest shake before the wind.

17786.text: ¶And the Lord said to Isaiah, “Go forth to meet Ahaz, you and She′ar‑jash′ub your son, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool on the highway to the Fuller’s Field,

17787.text: and say to him, ‘Take heed, be quiet, do not fear, and do not let your heart be faint because of these two smoldering stumps of firebrands, at the fierce anger of Rezin and Syria and the son of Remali′ah.

17788.text: Because Syria, with E′phraim and the son of Remali′ah, has devised evil against you, saying,

17789.text: “Let us go up against Judah and terrify it, and let us conquer it for ourselves, and set up the son of Ta′be‑el as king in the midst of it,”

17790.text: thus says the Lord God:¶▼It shall not stand,/_and it shall not come to pass.

17791.text: /For the head of Syria is Damascus,/_and the head of Damascus is Rezin.¶►(Within sixty‑five years E′phraim will be broken to pieces so that it will no longer be a people.)

17792.text: ¶And the head of E′phraim is Samar′ia,/_and the head of Samar′ia is the son of Remali′ah./If you will not believe,/_surely you shall not be established.’”

17794.text: “Ask a sign of the Lord your God; let it be deep as Sheol or high as heaven.”

17795.text: But Ahaz said, “I will not ask, and I will not put the Lord to the test.”

17796.text: And he said, “Hear then, O house of David! Is it too little for you to weary men, that you weary my God also?

17797.text: Therefore the Lord himself will give you a sign. Behold, a young woman shall conceive and bear a son, and shall call his name Imman′u‑el.

17798.text: He shall eat curds and honey when he knows how to refuse the evil and choose the good.

17799.text: For before the child knows how to refuse the evil and choose the good, the land before whose two kings you are in dread will be deserted.

17800.text: The Lord will bring upon you and upon your people and upon your father’s house such days as have not come since the day that E′phraim departed from Judah—the king of Assyria.”

17801.text: ¶In that day the Lord will whistle for the fly which is at the sources of the streams of Egypt, and for the bee which is in the land of Assyria.

17802.text: And they will all come and settle in the steep ravines, and in the clefts of the rocks, and on all the thornbushes, and on all the pastures.

17803.text: ¶In that day the Lord will shave with a razor which is hired beyond the River—with the king of Assyria—the head and the hair of the feet, and it will sweep away the beard also.

17804.text: ¶In that day a man will keep alive a young cow and two sheep;

17805.text: and because of the abundance of milk which they give, he will eat curds; for every one that is left in the land will eat curds and honey.

17806.text: ¶In that day every place where there used to be a thousand vines, worth a thousand shekels of silver, will become briers and thorns.

17807.text: With bow and arrows men will come there, for all the land will be briers and thorns;

17808.text: and as for all the hills which used to be hoed with a hoe, you will not come there for fear of briers and thorns; but they will become a place where cattle are let loose and where sheep tread.

17809.text: §¶Then the Lord said to me, “Take a large tablet and write upon it in common characters, ‘Belonging to Ma′her‑shal′al‑hash′baz.’”

17810.text: And I got reliable witnesses, Uri′ah the priest and Zechari′ah the son of Jeberechi′ah, to attest for me.

17811.text: And I went to the prophetess, and she conceived and bore a son. Then the Lord said to me, “Call his name Ma′her‑shal′al‑hash′baz;

17812.text: for before the child knows how to cry ‘My father’ or ‘My mother,’ the wealth of Damascus and the spoil of Samar′ia will be carried away before the king of Assyria.”

17814.text: “Because this people have refused the waters of Shilo′ah that flow gently, and melt in fear before Rezin and the son of Remali′ah;

17815.text: therefore, behold, the Lord is bringing up against them the waters of the River, mighty and many, the king of Assyria and all his glory; and it will rise over all its channels and go over all its banks;

17816.text: and it will sweep on into Judah, it will overflow and pass on, reaching even to the neck; and its outspread wings will fill the breadth of your land, O Imman′u‑el.”

17817.text: ¶Be broken, you peoples, and be dismayed;/_give ear, all you far countries;/gird yourselves and be dismayed;/_gird yourselves and be dismayed.

17818.text: /Take counsel together, but it will come to nought;/_speak a word, but it will not stand,/_for God is with us.

17819.text: ¶For the Lord spoke thus to me with his strong hand upon me, and warned me not to walk in the way of this people, saying:

17820.text: “Do not call conspiracy all that this people call conspiracy, and do not fear what they fear, nor be in dread.

17821.text: But the Lord of hosts, him you shall regard as holy; let him be your fear, and let him be your dread.

17822.text: And he will become a sanctuary, and a stone of offense, and a rock of stumbling to both houses of Israel, a trap and a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

17823.text: And many shall stumble thereon; they shall fall and be broken; they shall be snared and taken.”

17824.text: §¶Bind up the testimony, seal the teaching among my disciples.

17825.text: I will wait for the Lord, who is hiding his face from the house of Jacob, and I will hope in him.

17826.text: Behold, I and the children whom the Lord has given me are signs and portents in Israel from the Lord of hosts, who dwells on Mount Zion.

17827.text: And when they say to you, “Consult the mediums and the wizards who chirp and mutter,” should not a people consult their God? Should they consult the dead on behalf of the living?

17828.text: To the teaching and to the testimony! Surely for this word which they speak there is no dawn.

17829.text: They will pass through the land, greatly distressed and hungry; and when they are hungry, they will be enraged and will curse their king and their God, and turn their faces upward;

17830.text: and they will look to the earth, but behold, distress and darkness, the gloom of anguish; and they will be thrust into thick darkness.

17831.text: §¶But there will be no gloom for her that was in anguish. In the former time he brought into contempt the land of Zeb′ulun and the land of Naph′tali, but in the latter time he will make glorious the way of the sea, the land beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the nations.

17832.text: ¶The people who walked in darkness/_have seen a great light;/those who dwelt in a land of deep darkness,/_on them has light shined.

17833.text: /Thou hast multiplied the nation,/_thou hast increased its joy;/they rejoice before thee/_as with joy at the harvest,/_as men rejoice when they divide the spoil.

17834.text: /For the yoke of his burden,/_and the staff for his shoulder,/_the rod of his oppressor,/_thou hast broken as on the day of Mid′ian.

17835.text: /For every boot of the tramping warrior in battle tumult/_and every garment rolled in blood/_will be burned as fuel for the fire.

17836.text: /For to us a child is born,/_to us a son is given;/and the government will be upon his shoulder,/_and his name will be called/“Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God,/_Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace.”

17837.text: /Of the increase of his government and of peace/_there will be no end,/upon the throne of David, and over his kingdom,/_to establish it, and to uphold it/with justice and with righteousness/_from this time forth and for evermore./The zeal of the Lord of hosts will do this.

17838.text: §¶The Lord has sent a word against Jacob,/_and it will light upon Israel;

17839.text: /and all the people will know,/_E′phraim and the inhabitants of Samar′ia,/_who say in pride and in arrogance of heart:

17840.text: /“The bricks have fallen,/_but we will build with dressed stones;/the sycamores have been cut down,/_but we will put cedars in their place.”

17841.text: /So the Lord raises adversaries against them,/_and stirs up their enemies.

17842.text: /The Syrians on the east and the Philistines on the west/_devour Israel with open mouth./For all this his anger is not turned away/_and his hand is stretched out still.

17843.text: ¶The people did not turn to him who smote them,/_nor seek the Lord of hosts.

17844.text: /So the Lord cut off from Israel head and tail,/_palm branch and reed in one day—

17845.text: /the elder and honored man is the head,/_and the prophet who teaches lies is the tail;

17846.text: /for those who lead this people lead them astray,/_and those who are led by them are swallowed up.

17847.text: /Therefore the Lord does not rejoice over their young men,/_and has no compassion on their fatherless and widows;/for every one is godless and an evildoer,/_and every mouth speaks folly./For all this his anger is not turned away/_and his hand is stretched out still.

17848.text: ¶For wickedness burns like a fire,/_it consumes briers and thorns;/it kindles the thickets of the forest,/_and they roll upward in a column of smoke.

17849.text: /Through the wrath of the Lord of hosts/_the land is burned,/and the people are like fuel for the fire;/_no man spares his brother.

17850.text: /They snatch on the right, but are still hungry,/_and they devour on the left, but are not satisfied;/each devours his neighbor’s flesh,

17851.text: /Manas′seh E′phraim, and E′phraim Manas′seh,/_and together they are against Judah./For all this his anger is not turned away/_and his hand is stretched out still.

17852.text: ¶Woe to those who decree iniquitous decrees,/_and the writers who keep writing oppression,

17853.text: /to turn aside the needy from justice/_and to rob the poor of my people of their right,/that widows may be their spoil,/_and that they may make the fatherless their prey!

17854.text: /What will you do on the day of punishment,/_in the storm which will come from afar?/To whom will you flee for help,/_and where will you leave your wealth?

17855.text: /Nothing remains but to crouch among the prisoners/_or fall among the slain./For all this his anger is not turned away/_and his hand is stretched out still.

17856.text: §¶Ah, Assyria, the rod of my anger,/_the staff of my fury!

17857.text: /Against a godless nation I send him,/_and against the people of my wrath I command him,/to take spoil and seize plunder,/_and to tread them down like the mire of the streets.

17858.text: /But he does not so intend,/_and his mind does not so think;/but it is in his mind to destroy,/_and to cut off nations not a few;

17859.text: /for he says:/“Are not my commanders all kings?

17860.text: /Is not Calno like Car′chemish?/_Is not Hamath like Arpad?/_Is not Samar′ia like Damascus?

17861.text: /As my hand has reached to the kingdoms of the idols/_whose graven images were greater than those of Jerusalem and Samar′ia,

17862.text: /shall I not do to Jerusalem and her idols/_as I have done to Samar′ia and her images?”

17863.text: ¶When the Lord has finished all his work on Mount Zion and on Jerusalem he will punish the arrogant boasting of the king of Assyria and his haughty pride.

17864.text: For he says:¶▼“By the strength of my hand I have done it,/_and by my wisdom, for I have understanding;/I have removed the boundaries of peoples,/_and have plundered their treasures;/_like a bull I have brought down those who sat on thrones.

17865.text: /My hand has found like a nest/_the wealth of the peoples;/and as men gather eggs that have been forsaken/_so I have gathered all the earth;/and there was none that moved a wing,/_or opened the mouth, or chirped.”

17866.text: ¶Shall the axe vaunt itself over him who hews with it,/_or the saw magnify itself against him who wields it?/As if a rod should wield him who lifts it,/_or as if a staff should lift him who is not wood!

17867.text: /Therefore the Lord, the Lord of hosts,/_will send wasting sickness among his stout warriors,/and under his glory a burning will be kindled,/_like the burning of fire.

17868.text: /The light of Israel will become a fire,/_and his Holy One a flame;/and it will burn and devour/_his thorns and briers in one day.

17869.text: /The glory of his forest and of his fruitful land/_the Lord will destroy, both soul and body,/_and it will be as when a sick man wastes away.

17870.text: /The remnant of the trees of his forest will be so few/_that a child can write them down.

17871.text: §¶In that day the remnant of Israel and the survivors of the house of Jacob will no more lean upon him that smote them, but will lean upon the Lord, the Holy One of Israel, in truth.

17872.text: A remnant will return, the remnant of Jacob, to the mighty God.

17873.text: For though your people Israel be as the sand of the sea, only a remnant of them will return. Destruction is decreed, overflowing with righteousness.

17874.text: For the Lord, the Lord of hosts, will make a full end, as decreed, in the midst of all the earth.

17875.text: ¶Therefore thus says the Lord, the Lord of hosts: “O my people, who dwell in Zion, be not afraid of the Assyrians when they smite with the rod and lift up their staff against you as the Egyptians did.

17876.text: For in a very little while my indignation will come to an end, and my anger will be directed to their destruction.

17877.text: And the Lord of hosts will wield against them a scourge, as when he smote Mid′ian at the rock of Oreb; and his rod will be over the sea, and he will lift it as he did in Egypt.

17878.text: And in that day his burden will depart from your shoulder, and his yoke will be destroyed from your neck.”¶▼He has gone up from Rimmon,

17879.text: /_he has come to Ai′ath;/he has passed through Migron,/_at Michmash he stores his baggage;

17880.text: /they have crossed over the pass,/_at Geba they lodge for the night;/Ramah trembles,/_Gib′e‑ah of Saul has fled.

17881.text: /Cry aloud, O daughter of Gallim!/_Hearken, O La′ishah!/_Answer her, O An′athoth!

17882.text: /Madme′nah is in flight,/_the inhabitants of Gebim flee for safety.

17883.text: /This very day he will halt at Nob,/_he will shake his fist/_at the mount of the daughter of Zion,/_the hill of Jerusalem.

17884.text: ¶Behold, the Lord, the Lord of hosts/_will lop the boughs with terrifying power;/the great in height will be hewn down,/_and the lofty will be brought low.

17885.text: /He will cut down the thickets of the forest with an axe,/_and Lebanon with its majestic trees will fall.

17886.text: §¶There shall come forth a shoot from the stump of Jesse,/_and a branch shall grow out of his roots.

17887.text: /And the Spirit of the Lord shall rest upon him,/_the spirit of wisdom and understanding,/_the spirit of counsel and might,/_the spirit of knowledge and the fear of the Lord.

17888.text: /And his delight shall be in the fear of the Lord.¶He shall not judge by what his eyes see,/_or decide by what his ears hear;

17889.text: /but with righteousness he shall judge the poor,/_and decide with equity for the meek of the earth;/and he shall smite the earth with the rod of his mouth,/_and with the breath of his lips he shall slay the wicked.

17890.text: /Righteousness shall be the girdle of his waist,/_and faithfulness the girdle of his loins.

17891.text: ¶The wolf shall dwell with the lamb,/_and the leopard shall lie down with the kid,/and the calf and the lion and the fatling together,/_and a little child shall lead them.

17892.text: /The cow and the bear shall feed;/_their young shall lie down together;/_and the lion shall eat straw like the ox.

17893.text: /The sucking child shall play over the hole of the asp,/_and the weaned child shall put his hand on the adder’s den.

17894.text: /They shall not hurt or destroy/_in all my holy mountain;/for the earth shall be full of the knowledge of the Lord/_as the waters cover the sea.

17895.text: §¶In that day the root of Jesse shall stand as an ensign to the peoples; him shall the nations seek, and his dwellings shall be glorious.

17896.text: ¶In that day the Lord will extend his hand yet a second time to recover the remnant which is left of his people, from Assyria, from Egypt, from Pathros, from Ethiopia, from Elam, from Shinar, from Hamath, and from the coastlands of the sea.

17897.text: ¶He will raise an ensign for the nations,/_and will assemble the outcasts of Israel,/and gather the dispersed of Judah/_from the four corners of the earth.

17898.text: /The jealousy of E′phraim shall depart,/_and those who harass Judah shall be cut off;/E′phraim shall not be jealous of Judah,/_and Judah shall not harass E′phraim.

17899.text: /But they shall swoop down upon the shoulder of the Philistines in the west,/_and together they shall plunder the people of the east./They shall put forth their hand against Edom and Moab,/_and the Ammonites shall obey them.

17900.text: /And the Lord will utterly destroy/_the tongue of the sea of Egypt;/and will wave his hand over the River/_with his scorching wind,/and smite it into seven channels/_that men may cross dryshod.

17901.text: /And there will be a highway from Assyria/_for the remnant which is left of his people,/as there was for Israel/_when they came up from the land of Egypt.

17902.text: §¶You will say in that day:/_“I will give thanks to thee, O Lord,/_for though thou wast angry with me,/thy anger turned away,/_and thou didst comfort me.

17903.text: ¶“Behold, God is my salvation;/_I will trust, and will not be afraid;/for the Lord God is my strength and my song,/_and he has become my salvation.”

17904.text: ¶With joy you will draw water from the wells of salvation.

17905.text: And you will say in that day:¶▼“Give thanks to the Lord,/_call upon his name;/make known his deeds among the nations,/_proclaim that his name is exalted.

17906.text: ¶“Sing praises to the Lord, for he has done gloriously;/_let this be known in all the earth.

17907.text: /Shout, and sing for joy, O inhabitant of Zion,/_for great in your midst is the Holy One of Israel.”

17908.text: §¶The oracle concerning Babylon which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw.

17909.text: ¶On a bare hill raise a signal,/_cry aloud to them;/wave the hand for them to enter/_the gates of the nobles.

17910.text: /I myself have commanded my consecrated ones,/_have summoned my mighty men to execute my anger,/_my proudly exulting ones.

17911.text: ¶Hark, a tumult on the mountains/_as of a great multitude!/Hark, an uproar of kingdoms,/_of nations gathering together!/The Lord of hosts is mustering/_a host for battle.

17912.text: /They come from a distant land,/_from the end of the heavens,/the Lord and the weapons of his indignation,/_to destroy the whole earth.

17913.text: ¶Wail, for the day of the Lord is near;/_as destruction from the Almighty it will come!

17914.text: /Therefore all hands will be feeble,/_and every man’s heart will melt,

17915.text: /_and they will be dismayed./Pangs and agony will seize them;/_they will be in anguish like a woman in travail./They will look aghast at one another;/_their faces will be aflame.

17916.text: ¶Behold, the day of the Lord comes,/_cruel, with wrath and fierce anger,/to make the earth a desolation/_and to destroy its sinners from it.

17917.text: /For the stars of the heavens and their constellations/_will not give their light;/the sun will be dark at its rising/_and the moon will not shed its light.

17918.text: /I will punish the world for its evil,/_and the wicked for their iniquity;/I will put an end to the pride of the arrogant,/_and lay low the haughtiness of the ruthless.

17919.text: /I will make men more rare than fine gold,/_and mankind than the gold of Ophir.

17920.text: /Therefore I will make the heavens tremble,/_and the earth will be shaken out of its place,/at the wrath of the Lord of hosts/_in the day of his fierce anger.

17921.text: /And like a hunted gazelle,/_or like sheep with none to gather them,/every man will turn to his own people,/_and every man will flee to his own land.

17922.text: /Whoever is found will be thrust through,/_and whoever is caught will fall by the sword.

17923.text: /Their infants will be dashed in pieces/_before their eyes;/their houses will be plundered/_and their wives ravished.

17924.text: ¶Behold, I am stirring up the Medes against them,/_who have no regard for silver/_and do not delight in gold.

17925.text: /Their bows will slaughter the young men;/_they will have no mercy on the fruit of the womb;/_their eyes will not pity children.

17926.text: /And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms,/_the splendor and pride of the Chalde′ans,/will be like Sodom and Gomor′rah/_when God overthrew them.

17927.text: /It will never be inhabited/_or dwelt in for all generations;/no Arab will pitch his tent there,/_no shepherds will make their flocks lie down there.

17928.text: /But wild beasts will lie down there,/_and its houses will be full of howling creatures;/there ostriches will dwell,/_and there satyrs will dance.

17929.text: /Hyenas will cry in its towers,/_and jackals in the pleasant palaces;/its time is close at hand/_and its days will not be prolonged.

17930.text: §¶The Lord will have compassion on Jacob and will again choose Israel, and will set them in their own land, and aliens will join them and will cleave to the house of Jacob.

17931.text: And the peoples will take them and bring them to their place, and the house of Israel will possess them in the Lord’s land as male and female slaves; they will take captive those who were their captors, and rule over those who oppressed them.

17932.text: §¶When the Lord has given you rest from your pain and turmoil and the hard service with which you were made to serve,

17933.text: you will take up this taunt against the king of Babylon:¶▼“How the oppressor has ceased,/_the insolent fury ceased!

17934.text: /The Lord has broken the staff of the wicked,/_the scepter of rulers,

17935.text: /that smote the peoples in wrath/_with unceasing blows,/that ruled the nations in anger/_with unrelenting persecution.

17936.text: /The whole earth is at rest and quiet;/_they break forth into singing.

17937.text: /The cypresses rejoice at you,/_the cedars of Lebanon, saying,/‘Since you were laid low,/_no hewer comes up against us.’

17938.text: /Sheol beneath is stirred up/_to meet you when you come,/it rouses the shades to greet you,/_all who were leaders of the earth;/it raises from their thrones/_all who were kings of the nations.

17939.text: /All of them will speak/_and say to you:/‘You too have become as weak as we!/_You have become like us!’

17940.text: /Your pomp is brought down to Sheol,/_the sound of your harps;/maggots are the bed beneath you,/_and worms are your covering.

17941.text: ¶“How you are fallen from heaven,/_O Day Star, son of Dawn!/How you are cut down to the ground,/_you who laid the nations low!

17942.text: /You said in your heart,/_‘I will ascend to heaven;/above the stars of God/_I will set my throne on high;/I will sit on the mount of assembly/_in the far north;

17943.text: /I will ascend above the heights of the clouds,/_I will make myself like the Most High.’

17944.text: /But you are brought down to Sheol,/_to the depths of the Pit.

17945.text: /Those who see you will stare at you,/_and ponder over you:/‘Is this the man who made the earth tremble,/_who shook kingdoms,

17946.text: /who made the world like a desert/_and overthrew its cities,/_who did not let his prisoners go home?’

17947.text: /All the kings of the nations lie in glory,/_each in his own tomb;

17948.text: /but you are cast out, away from your sepulchre,/_like a loathed untimely birth,/clothed with the slain, those pierced by the sword,/_who go down to the stones of the Pit,/_like a dead body trodden under foot.

17949.text: /You will not be joined with them in burial,/_because you have destroyed your land,/_you have slain your people.¶“May the descendants of evildoers/_nevermore be named!

17950.text: /Prepare slaughter for his sons/_because of the guilt of their fathers,/lest they rise and possess the earth,/_and fill the face of the world with cities.”

17951.text: ¶“I will rise up against them,” says the Lord of hosts, “and will cut off from Babylon name and remnant, offspring and posterity, says the Lord.

17952.text: And I will make it a possession of the hedgehog, and pools of water, and I will sweep it with the broom of destruction, says the Lord of hosts.”

17953.text: §¶The Lord of hosts has sworn:/“As I have planned,/_so shall it be,/and as I have purposed,/_so shall it stand,

17954.text: /that I will break the Assyrian in my land,/_and upon my mountains trample him under foot;/and his yoke shall depart from them,/_and his burden from their shoulder.”

17955.text: /This is the purpose that is purposed/_concerning the whole earth;/and this is the hand that is stretched out/_over all the nations.

17956.text: /For the Lord of hosts has purposed,/_and who will annul it?/His hand is stretched out,/_and who will turn it back?

17957.text: §¶In the year that King Ahaz died came this oracle:

17958.text: ¶“Rejoice not, O Philistia, all of you,/_that the rod which smote you is broken,/for from the serpent’s root will come forth an adder,/_and its fruit will be a flying serpent.

17959.text: /And the first‑born of the poor will feed,/_and the needy lie down in safety;/but I will kill your root with famine,/_and your remnant I will slay.

17960.text: /Wail, O gate; cry, O city;/_melt in fear, O Philistia, all of you!/For smoke comes out of the north,/_and there is no straggler in his ranks.”

17961.text: ¶What will one answer the messengers of the nation?/“The Lord has founded Zion,/_and in her the afflicted of his people find refuge.”

17962.text: §¶An oracle concerning Moab./_Because Ar is laid waste in a night/_Moab is undone;/because Kir is laid waste in a night/_Moab is undone.

17963.text: /The daughter of Dibon has gone up/_to the high places to weep;/over Nebo and over Med′eba/_Moab wails./On every head is baldness,/_every beard is shorn;

17964.text: /in the streets they gird on sackcloth;/_on the housetops and in the squares/_every one wails and melts in tears.

17965.text: /Heshbon and Ele‑a′leh cry out,/_their voice is heard as far as Jahaz;/therefore the armed men of Moab cry aloud;/_his soul trembles.

17966.text: /My heart cries out for Moab;/_his fugitives flee to Zo′ar,/_to Eg′lath‑shelish′iyah./For at the ascent of Luhith/_they go up weeping;/on the road to Horona′im/_they raise a cry of destruction;

17967.text: /the waters of Nimrim/_are a desolation;/the grass is withered, the new growth fails,/_the verdure is no more.

17968.text: /Therefore the abundance they have gained/_and what they have laid up/they carry away/_over the Brook of the Willows.

17969.text: /For a cry has gone/_round the land of Moab;/the wailing reaches to Egla′im,/_the wailing reaches to Beer‑e′lim.

17970.text: /For the waters of Dibon are full of blood;/_yet I will bring upon Dibon even more,/a lion for those of Moab who escape,/_for the remnant of the land.

17971.text: ¶They have sent lambs/_to the ruler of the land,/from Sela, by way of the desert,/_to the mount of the daughter of Zion.

17972.text: /Like fluttering birds,/_like scattered nestlings,/so are the daughters of Moab/_at the fords of the Arnon.

17973.text: /“Give counsel,/_grant justice;/make your shade like night/_at the height of noon;/hide the outcasts,/_betray not the fugitive;

17974.text: /let the outcasts of Moab/_sojourn among you;/be a refuge to them/_from the destroyer./When the oppressor is no more,/_and destruction has ceased,/and he who tramples under foot/_has vanished from the land,

17975.text: /then a throne will be established in steadfast love/_and on it will sit in faithfulness/_in the tent of David/one who judges and seeks justice/_and is swift to do righteousness.”

17976.text: ¶We have heard of the pride of Moab,/_how proud he was;/of his arrogance, his pride, and his insolence—/_his boasts are false.

17977.text: /Therefore let Moab wail,/_let every one wail for Moab./Mourn, utterly stricken,/_for the raisin‑cakes of Kir‑har′eseth.

17978.text: ¶For the fields of Heshbon languish,/_and the vine of Sibmah;/the lords of the nations/_have struck down its branches,/which reached to Jazer/_and strayed to the desert;/its shoots spread abroad/_and passed over the sea.

17979.text: /Therefore I weep with the weeping of Jazer/_for the vine of Sibmah;/I drench you with my tears,/_O Heshbon and Ele‑a′leh;/for upon your fruit and your harvest/_the battle shout has fallen.

17980.text: /And joy and gladness are taken away/_from the fruitful field;/and in the vineyards no songs are sung,/_no shouts are raised;/no treader treads out wine in the presses;/_the vintage shout is hushed.

17981.text: /Therefore my soul moans like a lyre for Moab,/_and my heart for Kir‑he′res.

17982.text: ¶And when Moab presents himself, when he wearies himself upon the high place, when he comes to his sanctuary to pray, he will not prevail.

17983.text: ¶This is the word which the Lord spoke concerning Moab in the past.

17984.text: But now the Lord says, “In three years, like the years of a hireling, the glory of Moab will be brought into contempt, in spite of all his great multitude, and those who survive will be very few and feeble.”

17985.text: §¶An oracle concerning Damascus./Behold, Damascus will cease to be a city,/_and will become a heap of ruins.

17986.text: /Her cities will be deserted for ever;/_they will be for flocks,/_which will lie down, and none will make them afraid.

17987.text: /The fortress will disappear from E′phraim,/_and the kingdom from Damascus;/and the remnant of Syria will be/_like the glory of the children of Israel,/_says the Lord of hosts.

17988.text: ¶And in that day/_the glory of Jacob will be brought low,/_and the fat of his flesh will grow lean.

17989.text: /And it shall be as when the reaper gathers standing grain/_and his arm harvests the ears,/and as when one gleans the ears of grain/_in the Valley of Reph′aim.

17990.text: /Gleanings will be left in it,/_as when an olive tree is beaten—/two or three berries/_in the top of the highest bough,/four or five/_on the branches of a fruit tree,/_says the Lord God of Israel.

17991.text: ¶In that day men will regard their Maker, and their eyes will look to the Holy One of Israel;

17992.text: they will not have regard for the altars, the work of their hands, and they will not look to what their own fingers have made, either the Ashe′rim or the altars of incense.

17993.text: ¶In that day their strong cities will be like the deserted places of the Hivites and the Amorites, which they deserted because of the children of Israel, and there will be desolation.

17994.text: ¶For you have forgotten the God of your salvation,/_and have not remembered the Rock of your refuge;/therefore, though you plant pleasant plants/_and set out slips of an alien god,

17995.text: /though you make them grow on the day that you plant them,/_and make them blossom in the morning that you sow;/yet the harvest will flee away/_in a day of grief and incurable pain.

17996.text: ¶Ah, the thunder of many peoples,/_they thunder like the thundering of the sea!/Ah, the roar of nations,/_they roar like the roaring of mighty waters!

17997.text: /The nations roar like the roaring of many waters,/_but he will rebuke them, and they will flee far away,/chased like chaff on the mountains before the wind/_and whirling dust before the storm.

17998.text: /At evening time, behold, terror!/_Before morning, they are no more!/This is the portion of those who despoil us,/_and the lot of those who plunder us.

17999.text: §¶Ah, land of whirring wings/_which is beyond the rivers of Ethiopia;

18000.text: /which sends ambassadors by the Nile,/_in vessels of papyrus upon the waters!/Go, you swift messengers,/_to a nation, tall and smooth,/to a people feared near and far,/_a nation mighty and conquering,/_whose land the rivers divide.

18001.text: ¶All you inhabitants of the world,/_you who dwell on the earth,/when a signal is raised on the mountains, look!/_When a trumpet is blown, hear!

18002.text: /For thus the Lord said to me:/“I will quietly look from my dwelling/_like clear heat in sunshine,/_like a cloud of dew in the heat of harvest.”

18003.text: /For before the harvest, when the blossom is over,/_and the flower becomes a ripening grape,/he will cut off the shoots with pruning hooks,/_and the spreading branches he will hew away.

18004.text: /They shall all of them be left/_to the birds of prey of the mountains/_and to the beasts of the earth./And the birds of prey will summer upon them,/_and all the beasts of the earth will winter upon them,

18005.text: ¶At that time gifts will be brought to the Lord of hosts¶▼from a people tall and smooth,/_from a people feared near and far,/a nation mighty and conquering,/_whose land the rivers divide,¶►to Mount Zion, the place of the name of the Lord of hosts.

18006.text: §¶An oracle concerning Egypt./Behold, the Lord is riding on a swift cloud/_and comes to Egypt;/and the idols of Egypt will tremble at his presence,/_and the heart of the Egyptians will melt within them.

18007.text: /And I will stir up Egyptians against Egyptians,/_and they will fight, every man against his brother/_and every man against his neighbor,/_city against city, kingdom against kingdom;

18008.text: /and the spirit of the Egyptians within them will be emptied out,/_and I will confound their plans;/and they will consult the idols and the sorcerers,/_and the mediums and the wizards;

18009.text: /and I will give over the Egyptians/_into the hand of a hard master;/and a fierce king will rule over them,/_says the Lord, the Lord of hosts.

18010.text: ¶And the waters of the Nile will be dried up,/_and the river will be parched and dry;

18011.text: /and its canals will become foul,/_and the branches of Egypt’s Nile will diminish and dry up,/_reeds and rushes will rot away.

18012.text: /There will be bare places by the Nile,/_on the brink of the Nile,/and all that is sown by the Nile will dry up,/_be driven away, and be no more.

18013.text: /The fishermen will mourn and lament,/_all who cast hook in the Nile;/and they will languish/_who spread nets upon the water.

18014.text: /The workers in combed flax will be in despair,/_and the weavers of white cotton.

18015.text: /Those who are the pillars of the land will be crushed,/_and all who work for hire will be grieved.

18016.text: ¶The princes of Zo′an are utterly foolish;/_the wise counselors of Pharoah give stupid counsel./How can you say to Pharaoh,/_“I am a son of the wise,/_a son of ancient kings”?

18017.text: /Where then are your wise men?/_Let them tell you and make known/_what the Lord of hosts has purposed against Egypt.

18018.text: /The princes of Zo′an have become fools,/_and the princes of Memphis are deluded;/those who are the cornerstones of her tribes/_have led Egypt astray.

18019.text: /The Lord has mingled within her/_a spirit of confusion;/and they have made Egypt stagger in all her doings/_as a drunken man staggers in his vomit.

18020.text: /And there will be nothing for Egypt/_which head or tail, palm branch or reed, may do.

18021.text: ¶In that day the Egyptians will be like women, and tremble with fear before the hand which the Lord of hosts shakes over them.

18022.text: And the land of Judah will become a terror to the Egyptians; every one to whom it is mentioned will fear because of the purpose which the Lord of hosts has purposed against them.

18023.text: §¶In that day there will be five cities in the land of Egypt which speak the language of Canaan and swear allegiance to the Lord of hosts. One of these will be called the City of the Sun.

18024.text: ¶In that day there will be an altar to the Lord in the midst of the land of Egypt, and a pillar to the Lord at its border.

18025.text: It will be a sign and a witness to the Lord of hosts in the land of Egypt; when they cry to the Lord because of oppressors he will send them a savior, and will defend and deliver them.

18026.text: And the Lord will make himself known to the Egyptians; and the Egyptians will know the Lord in that day and worship with sacrifice and burnt offering, and they will make vows to the Lord and perform them.

18027.text: And the Lord will smite Egypt, smiting and healing, and they will return to the Lord, and he will heed their supplications and heal them.

18028.text: ¶In that day there will be a highway from Egypt to Assyria, and the Assyrian will come into Egypt, and the Egyptian into Assyria, and the Egyptians will worship with the Assyrians.

18029.text: ¶In that day Israel will be the third with Egypt and Assyria, a blessing in the midst of the earth,

18030.text: whom the Lord of hosts has blessed, saying, “Blessed be Egypt my people, and Assyria the work of my hands, and Israel my heritage.”

18031.text: §¶In the year that the commander in chief, who was sent by Sargon the king of Assyria, came to Ashdod and fought against it and took it,—

18032.text: at that time the Lord had spoken by Isaiah the son of Amoz, saying, “Go, and loose the sackcloth from your loins and take off your shoes from your feet,” and he had done so, walking naked and barefoot—

18033.text: the Lord said, “As my servant Isaiah has walked naked and barefoot for three years as a sign and a portent against Egypt and Ethiopia,

18034.text: so shall the king of Assyria lead away the Egyptians captives and the Ethiopians exiles, both the young and the old, naked and barefoot, with buttocks uncovered, to the shame of Egypt.

18035.text: Then they shall be dismayed and confounded because of Ethiopia their hope and of Egypt their boast.

18036.text: And the inhabitants of this coastland will say in that day, ‘Behold, this is what has happened to those in whom we hoped and to whom we fled for help to be delivered from the king of Assyria! And we, how shall we escape?’”

18037.text: §¶The oracle concerning the wilderness of the sea./As whirlwinds in the Negeb sweep on,/_it comes from the desert,/_from a terrible land.

18038.text: /A stern vision is told to me;/_the plunderer plunders,/_and the destroyer destroys./Go up, O Elam,/_lay siege, O Media;/all the sighing she has caused/_I bring to an end.

18039.text: /Therefore my loins are filled with anguish;/_pangs have seized me,/_like the pangs of a woman in travail;/I am bowed down so that I cannot hear,/_I am dismayed so that I cannot see.

18040.text: /My mind reels, horror has appalled me;/_the twilight I longed for/_has been turned for me into trembling.

18041.text: /They prepare the table,/_they spread the rugs,/_they eat, they drink./Arise, O princes,/_oil the shield!

18042.text: /For thus the Lord said to me:/“Go, set a watchman,/_let him announce what he sees.

18043.text: /When he sees riders, horsemen in pairs,/_riders on asses, riders on camels,/let him listen diligently,/_very diligently.”

18044.text: /Then he who saw cried:/“Upon a watchtower I stand, O Lord,/_continually by day,/and at my post I am stationed/_whole nights.

18045.text: /And behold, here come riders,/_horsemen in pairs!”/And he answered,/_“Fallen, fallen is Babylon;/and all the images of her gods/_he has shattered to the ground.”

18046.text: /O my threshed and winnowed one,/_what I have heard from the Lord of hosts,/_the God of Israel, I announce to you.

18047.text: ¶The oracle concerning Dumah./One is calling to me from Se′ir,/_“Watchman, what of the night?/_Watchman, what of the night?”

18048.text: /The watchman says:/“Morning comes, and also the night./_If you will inquire, inquire;/_come back again.”

18049.text: ¶The oracle concerning Arabia./In the thickets in Arabia you will lodge,/_O caravans of De′danites.

18050.text: /To the thirsty bring water,/_meet the fugitive with bread,/_O inhabitants of the land of Tema.

18051.text: /For they have fled from the swords,/_from the drawn sword,/from the bent bow,/_and from the press of battle.

18052.text: ¶For thus the Lord said to me, “Within a year, according to the years of a hireling, all the glory of Kedar will come to an end;

18053.text: and the remainder of the archers of the mighty men of the sons of Kedar will be few; for the Lord, the God of Israel, has spoken.”

18054.text: §¶The oracle concerning the valley of vision./What do you mean that you have gone up,/_all of you, to the housetops,

18055.text: /you who are full of shoutings,/_tumultuous city, exultant town?/Your slain are not slain with the sword/_or dead in battle.

18056.text: /All your rulers have fled together,/_without the bow they were captured./All of you who were found were captured,/_though they had fled far away.

18057.text: /Therefore I said:/“Look away from me,/_let me weep bitter tears;/do not labor to comfort me/_for the destruction of the daughter of my people.”

18058.text: ¶For the Lord God of hosts has a day/_of tumult and trampling and confusion/_in the valley of vision,/a battering down of walls/_and a shouting to the mountains.

18059.text: /And Elam bore the quiver/_with chariots and horsemen,/_and Kir uncovered the shield.

18060.text: /Your choicest valleys were full of chariots,/_and the horsemen took their stand at the gates.

18061.text: /He has taken away the covering of Judah.¶►In that day you looked to the weapons of the House of the Forest,

18062.text: and you saw that the breaches of the city of David were many, and you collected the waters of the lower pool,

18063.text: and you counted the houses of Jerusalem, and you broke down the houses to fortify the wall.

18064.text: You made a reservoir between the two walls for the water of the old pool. But you did not look to him who did it, or have regard for him who planned it long ago.

18065.text: ¶In that day the Lord God of hosts/_called to weeping and mourning,/_to baldness and girding with sackcloth;

18066.text: /and behold, joy and gladness,/_slaying oxen and killing sheep,/_eating flesh and drinking wine./“Let us eat and drink,/_for tomorrow we die.”

18067.text: /The Lord of hosts has revealed himself in my ears:/“Surely this iniquity will not be forgiven you/_till you die,”/_says the Lord God of hosts.

18068.text: §¶Thus says the Lord God of hosts, “Come, go to this steward, to Shebna, who is over the household, and say to him:

18069.text: What have you to do here and whom have you here, that you have hewn here a tomb for yourself, you who hew a tomb on the height, and carve a habitation for yourself in the rock?

18070.text: Behold, the Lord will hurl you away violently, O you strong man. He will seize firm hold on you,

18071.text: and whirl you round and round, and throw you like a ball into a wide land; there you shall die, and there shall be your splendid chariots, you shame of your master’s house.

18072.text: I will thrust you from your office, and you will be cast down from your station.

18073.text: In that day I will call my servant Eli′akim the son of Hilki′ah,

18074.text: and I will clothe him with your robe, and will bind your girdle on him, and will commit your authority to his hand; and he shall be a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem and to the house of Judah.

18075.text: And I will place on his shoulder the key of the house of David; he shall open, and none shall shut; and he shall shut, and none shall open.

18076.text: And I will fasten him like a peg in a sure place, and he will become a throne of honor to his father’s house.

18077.text: And they will hang on him the whole weight of his father’s house, the offspring and issue, every small vessel, from the cups to all the flagons.

18078.text: In that day, says the Lord of hosts, the peg that was fastened in a sure place will give way; and it will be cut down and fall, and the burden that was upon it will be cut off, for the Lord has spoken.”

18079.text: §¶The oracle concerning Tyre./Wail, O ships of Tarshish,/_for Tyre is laid waste, without house or haven!/From the land of Cyprus/_it is revealed to them.

18080.text: /Be still, O inhabitants of the coast,/_O merchants of Sidon;/your messengers passed over the sea

18081.text: /_and were on many waters;/your revenue was the grain of Shihor,/_the harvest of the Nile;/_you were the merchant of the nations.

18082.text: /Be ashamed, O Sidon, for the sea has spoken,/_the stronghold of the sea, saying:/“I have neither travailed nor given birth,/_I have neither reared young men/_nor brought up virgins.”

18083.text: /When the report comes to Egypt,/_they will be in anguish over the report about Tyre.

18084.text: /Pass over to Tarshish,/_wail, O inhabitants of the coast!

18085.text: /Is this your exultant city/_whose origin is from days of old,/whose feet carried her/_to settle afar?

18086.text: /Who has purposed this/_against Tyre, the bestower of crowns,/whose merchants were princes,/_whose traders were the honored of the earth?

18087.text: /The Lord of hosts has purposed it,/_to defile the pride of all glory,/_to dishonor all the honored of the earth.

18088.text: /Overflow your land like the Nile,/_O daughter of Tarshish;/_there is no restraint any more.

18089.text: /He has stretched out his hand over the sea,/_he has shaken the kingdoms;/the Lord has given command concerning Canaan/_to destroy its strongholds.

18090.text: /And he said:/“You will no more exult,/_O oppressed virgin daughter of Sidon;/arise, pass over to Cyprus,/_even there you will have no rest.”

18091.text: ¶Behold the land of the Chalde′ans! This is the people; it was not Assyria. They destined Tyre for wild beasts. They erected their siege towers, they razed her palaces, they made her a ruin.

18092.text: ¶Wail, O ships of Tarshish,/_for your stronghold is laid waste.

18093.text: ¶In that day Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years, like the days of one king. At the end of seventy years, it will happen to Tyre as in the song of the harlot:

18094.text: ¶“Take a harp,/_go about the city,/_O forgotten harlot!/Make sweet melody,/_sing many songs,/_that you may be remembered.”

18095.text: ¶At the end of seventy years, the Lord will visit Tyre, and she will return to her hire, and will play the harlot with all the kingdoms of the world upon the face of the earth.

18096.text: Her merchandise and her hire will be dedicated to the Lord; it will not be stored or hoarded, but her merchandise will supply abundant food and fine clothing for those who dwell before the Lord.

18097.text: §¶Behold, the Lord will lay waste the earth and make it desolate,/_and he will twist its surface and scatter its inhabitants.

18098.text: /And it shall be, as with the people,/_so with the priest;/_as with the slave, so with his master;/_as with the maid, so with her mistress;/as with the buyer, so with the seller;/_as with the lender, so with the borrower;/_as with the creditor, so with the debtor.

18099.text: /The earth shall be utterly laid waste and utterly despoiled;/_for the Lord has spoken this word.

18100.text: ¶The earth mourns and withers,/_the world languishes and withers;/_the heavens languish together with the earth.

18101.text: /The earth lies polluted/_under its inhabitants;/for they have transgressed the laws,/_violated the statutes,/_broken the everlasting covenant.

18102.text: /Therefore a curse devours the earth,/_and its inhabitants suffer for their guilt;/therefore the inhabitants of the earth are scorched,/_and few men are left.

18103.text: /The wine mourns,/_the vine languishes,/_all the merry‑hearted sigh.

18104.text: /The mirth of the timbrels is stilled,/_the noise of the jubilant has ceased,/_the mirth of the lyre is stilled.

18105.text: /No more do they drink wine with singing;/_strong drink is bitter to those who drink it.

18106.text: /The city of chaos is broken down,/_every house is shut up so that none can enter.

18107.text: /There is an outcry in the streets for lack of wine;/_all joy has reached its eventide;/_the gladness of the earth is banished.

18108.text: /Desolation is left in the city,/_the gates are battered into ruins.

18109.text: /For thus it shall be in the midst of the earth/_among the nations,/as when an olive tree is beaten,/_as at the gleaning when the vintage is done.

18110.text: ¶They lift up their voices, they sing for joy;/_over the majesty of the Lord they shout from the west.

18111.text: /Therefore in the east give glory to the Lord;/_in the coastlands of the sea, to the name of the Lord, the God of Israel.

18112.text: /From the ends of the earth we hear songs of praise,/_of glory to the Righteous One./But I say, “I pine away,/_I pine away. Woe is me!/For the treacherous deal treacherously,/_the treacherous deal very treacherously.”

18113.text: ¶Terror, and the pit, and the snare/_are upon you, O inhabitant of the earth!

18114.text: /He who flees at the sound of the terror/_shall fall into the pit;/and he who climbs out of the pit/_shall be caught in the snare./For the windows of heaven are opened,/_and the foundations of the earth tremble.

18115.text: /The earth is utterly broken,/_the earth is rent asunder,/_the earth is violently shaken.

18116.text: /The earth staggers like a drunken man,/_it sways like a hut;/its transgression lies heavy upon it,/_and it falls, and will not rise again.

18117.text: ¶On that day the Lord will punish/_the host of heaven, in heaven,/_and the kings of the earth, on the earth.

18118.text: /They will be gathered together/_as prisoners in a pit;/they will be shut up in a prison,/_and after many days they will be punished.

18119.text: /Then the moon will be confounded,/_and the sun ashamed;/for the Lord of hosts will reign/_on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem/and before his elders he will manifest his glory.

18120.text: §¶O Lord, thou art my God;/I will exalt thee, I will praise thy name;/for thou hast done wonderful things,/_plans formed of old, faithful and sure.

18121.text: /For thou hast made the city a heap,/_the fortified city a ruin;/the palace of aliens is a city no more,/_it will never be rebuilt.

18122.text: /Therefore strong peoples will glorify thee;/_cities of ruthless nations will fear thee.

18123.text: /For thou hast been a stronghold to the poor,/_a stronghold to the needy in his distress,/_a shelter from the storm and a shade from the heat;/for the blast of the ruthless is like a storm against a wall,

18124.text: /_like heat in a dry place./Thou dost subdue the noise of the aliens;/_as heat by the shade of a cloud,/_so the song of the ruthless is stilled.

18125.text: ¶On this mountain the Lord of hosts will make for all peoples a feast of fat things, a feast of wine on the lees, of fat things full of marrow, of wine on the lees well refined.

18126.text: And he will destroy on this mountain the covering that is cast over all peoples, the veil that is spread over all nations.

18127.text: He will swallow up death for ever, and the Lord God will wipe away tears from all faces, and the reproach of his people he will take away from all the earth; for the Lord has spoken.

18128.text: ¶It will be said on that day, “Lo, this is our God; we have waited for him, that he might save us. This is the Lord; we have waited for him; let us be glad and rejoice in his salvation.”

18129.text: ¶For the hand of the Lord will rest on this mountain, and Moab shall be trodden down in his place, as straw is trodden down in a dung‑pit.

18130.text: And he will spread out his hands in the midst of it as a swimmer spreads his hands out to swim; but the Lord will lay low his pride together with the skill of his hands.

18131.text: And the high fortifications of his walls he will bring down, lay low, and cast to the ground, even to the dust.

18132.text: §¶In that day this song will be sung in the land of Judah:¶▼“We have a strong city;/_he sets up salvation/_as walls and bulwarks.

18133.text: /Open the gates,/_that the righteous nation which keeps faith/_may enter in.

18134.text: /Thou dost keep him in perfect peace,/_whose mind is stayed on thee,/_because he trusts in thee.

18135.text: /Trust in the Lord for ever,/_for the Lord God/_is an everlasting rock.

18136.text: /For he has brought low/_the inhabitants of the height,/_the lofty city./He lays it low, lays it low to the ground,/_casts it to the dust.

18137.text: /The foot tramples it,/_the feet of the poor,/_the steps of the needy.”

18138.text: ¶The way of the righteous is level;/_thou dost make smooth the path of the righteous.

18139.text: /In the path of thy judgments,/_O Lord, we wait for thee;/thy memorial name/_is the desire of our soul.

18140.text: /My soul yearns for thee in the night,/_my spirit within me earnestly seeks thee./For when thy judgments are in the earth,/_the inhabitants of the world learn righteousness.

18141.text: /If favor is shown to the wicked,/_he does not learn righteousness;/in the land of uprightness he deals perversely/_and does not see the majesty of the Lord.

18142.text: /O Lord, thy hand is lifted up,/_but they see it not./Let them see thy zeal for thy people, and be ashamed./_Let the fire for thy adversaries consume them.

18143.text: /O Lord, thou wilt ordain peace for us,/_thou hast wrought for us all our works.

18144.text: /O Lord our God,/_other lords besides thee have ruled over us,/_but thy name alone we acknowledge.

18145.text: /They are dead, they will not live;/_they are shades, they will not arise;/to that end thou hast visited them with destruction/_and wiped out all remembrance of them.

18146.text: /But thou hast increased the nation, O Lord,/_thou hast increased the nation; thou art glorified;/_thou hast enlarged all the borders of the land.

18147.text: ¶O Lord, in distress they sought thee,/_they poured out a prayer/_when thy chastening was upon them.

18148.text: /Like a woman with child,/_who writhes and cries out in her pangs,/_when she is near her time,/so were we because of thee, O Lord;

18149.text: /_we were with child, we writhed,/_we have as it were brought forth wind./We have wrought no deliverance in the earth,/_and the inhabitants of the world have not fallen.

18150.text: /Thy dead shall live, their bodies shall rise./_O dwellers in the dust, awake and sing for joy!/For thy dew is a dew of light,/_and on the land of the shades thou wilt let it fall.

18151.text: ¶Come, my people, enter your chambers,/_and shut your doors behind you;/hide yourselves for a little while/_until the wrath is past.

18152.text: /For behold, the Lord is coming forth out of his place/_to punish the inhabitants of the earth for their iniquity,/and the earth will disclose the blood shed upon her,/_and will no more cover her slain.

18153.text: §¶In that day the Lord with his hard and great and strong sword will punish Levi′athan the fleeing serpent, Levi′athan the twisting serpent, and he will slay the dragon that is in the sea.

18154.text: ¶In that day:/“A pleasant vineyard, sing of it!

18155.text: /_I, the Lord, am its keeper;/_every moment I water it./Lest any one harm it,/_I guard it night and day;

18156.text: /_I have no wrath./Would that I had thorns and briers to battle!/_I would set out against them,/_I would burn them up together.

18157.text: /Or let them lay hold of my protection,/_let them make peace with me,/_let them make peace with me.”

18158.text: ¶In days to come Jacob shall take root,/_Israel shall blossom and put forth shoots,/_and fill the whole world with fruit.

18159.text: ¶Has he smitten them as he smote those who smote them?/_Or have they been slain as their slayers were slain?

18160.text: /Measure by measure, by exile thou didst contend with them;/_he removed them with his fierce blast in the day of the east wind.

18161.text: /Therefore by this the guilt of Jacob will be expiated,/_and this will be the full fruit of the removal of his sin:/when he makes all the stones of the altars/_like chalkstones crushed to pieces,/_no Ashe′rim or incense altars will remain standing.

18162.text: /For the fortified city is solitary,/_a habitation deserted and forsaken, like the wilderness;/there the calf grazes,/_there he lies down, and strips its branches.

18163.text: /When its boughs are dry, they are broken;/_women come and make a fire of them./For this is a people without discernment;/_therefore he who made them will not have compassion on them,/_he that formed them will show them no favor.

18164.text: ¶In that day from the river Euphra′tes to the Brook of Egypt the Lord will thresh out the grain, and you will be gathered one by one, O people of Israel.

18165.text: And in that day a great trumpet will be blown, and those who were lost in the land of Assyria and those who were driven out to the land of Egypt will come and worship the Lord on the holy mountain at Jerusalem.

18166.text: §¶Woe to the proud crown of the drunkards of E′phraim,/_and to the fading flower of its glorious beauty,/_which is on the head of the rich valley of those overcome with wine!

18167.text: /Behold, the Lord has one who is mighty and strong;/_like a storm of hail, a destroying tempest,/like a storm of mighty, overflowing waters,/_he will cast down to the earth with violence.

18168.text: /The proud crown of the drunkards of E′phraim/_will be trodden under foot;

18169.text: /and the fading flower of its glorious beauty,/_which is on the head of the rich valley,/will be like a first‑ripe fig before the summer:/_when a man sees it, he eats it up/_as soon as it is in his hand.

18170.text: ¶In that day the Lord of hosts will be a crown of glory,/_and a diadem of beauty, to the remnant of his people;

18171.text: /and a spirit of justice to him who sits in judgment,/_and strength to those who turn back the battle at the gate.

18172.text: ¶These also reel with wine/_and stagger with strong drink;/the priest and the prophet reel with strong drink,/_they are confused with wine,/_they stagger with strong drink;/they err in vision,/_they stumble in giving judgment.

18173.text: /For all tables are full of vomit,/_no place is without filthiness.

18174.text: ¶“Whom will he teach knowledge,/_and to whom will he explain the message?/Those who are weaned from the milk,/_those taken from the breast?

18175.text: /For it is precept upon precept, precept upon precept,/_line upon line, line upon line,/_here a little, there a little.”

18176.text: ¶Nay, but by men of strange lips/_and with an alien tongue/the Lord will speak to this people,

18177.text: /_to whom he has said,/“This is rest;/_give rest to the weary;/and this is repose”;/_yet they would not hear.

18178.text: /Therefore the word of the Lord will be to them/precept upon precept, precept upon precept,/_line upon line, line upon line,/_here a little, there a little;/that they may go, and fall backward,/_and be broken, and snared, and taken.

18179.text: ¶Therefore hear the word of the Lord, you scoffers,/_who rule this people in Jerusalem!

18180.text: /Because you have said, “We have made a covenant with death,/_and with Sheol we have an agreement;/when the overwhelming scourge passes through/_it will not come to us;/for we have made lies our refuge,/_and in falsehood we have taken shelter”;

18181.text: /therefore thus says the Lord God,/“Behold, I am laying in Zion for a foundation/_a stone, a tested stone,/a precious cornerstone, of a sure foundation:/_‘He who believes will not be in haste.’

18182.text: /And I will make justice the line,/_and righteousness the plummet;/and hail will sweep away the refuge of lies,/_and waters will overwhelm the shelter.”

18183.text: /Then your covenant with death will be annulled,/_and your agreement with Sheol will not stand;/when the overwhelming scourge passes through/_you will be beaten down by it.

18184.text: /As often as it passes through it will take you;/_for morning by morning it will pass through,/_by day and by night;/and it will be sheer terror to understand the message.

18185.text: /For the bed is too short to stretch oneself on it,/_and the covering too narrow to wrap oneself in it.

18186.text: /For the Lord will rise up as on Mount Pera′zim,/_he will be wroth as in the valley of Gibeon;/to do his deed—strange is his deed!/_and to work his work—alien is his work!

18187.text: /Now therefore do not scoff,/_lest your bonds be made strong;/for I have heard a decree of destruction/_from the Lord God of hosts upon the whole land.

18188.text: ¶Give ear, and hear my voice;/_hearken, and hear my speech.

18189.text: /Does he who plows for sowing plow continually?/_does he continually open and harrow his ground?

18190.text: /When he has leveled its surface,/_does he not scatter dill, sow cummin,/and put in wheat in rows/_and barley in its proper place,/_and spelt as the border?

18191.text: /For he is instructed aright;/_his God teaches him.

18192.text: ¶Dill is not threshed with a threshing sledge,/_nor is a cart wheel rolled over cummin;/but dill is beaten out with a stick,/_and cummin with a rod.
