18193.text: /Does one crush bread grain?/_No, he does not thresh it for ever;/when he drives his cart wheel over it/_with his horses, he does not crush it.

18194.text: /This also comes from the Lord of hosts;/_he is wonderful in counsel,/_and excellent in wisdom.

18195.text: §¶Ho Ariel, Ariel,/the city where David encamped!/Add year to year;/_let the feasts run their round.

18196.text: /Yet I will distress Ariel,/_and there shall be moaning and lamentation,/_and she shall be to me like an Ariel.

18197.text: /And I will encamp against you round about,/_and will besiege you with towers/_and I will raise siegeworks against you.

18198.text: /Then deep from the earth you shall speak,/_from low in the dust your words shall come;/your voice shall come from the ground like the voice of a ghost,/_and your speech shall whisper out of the dust.

18199.text: ¶But the multitude of your foes shall be like small dust,/_and the multitude of the ruthless like passing chaff./And in an instant, suddenly,

18200.text: /_you will be visited by the Lord of hosts/with thunder and with earthquake and great noise,/_with whirlwind and tempest, and the flame of a devouring fire.

18201.text: /And the multitude of all the nations that fight against Ariel,/_all that fight against her and her stronghold and distress her,/_shall be like a dream, a vision of the night.

18202.text: /As when a hungry man dreams he is eating/_and awakes with his hunger not satisfied,/or as when a thirsty man dreams he is drinking/_and awakes faint, with his thirst not quenched,/so shall the multitude of all the nations be/_that fight against Mount Zion.

18203.text: ¶Stupefy yourselves and be in a stupor,/_blind yourselves and be blind!/Be drunk, but not with wine;/_stagger, but not with strong drink!

18204.text: /For the Lord has poured out upon you/_a spirit of deep sleep,/and has closed your eyes, the prophets,/_and covered your heads, the seers.

18205.text: ¶And the vision of all this has become to you like the words of a book that is sealed. When men give it to one who can read, saying, “Read this,” he says, “I cannot, for it is sealed.”

18206.text: And when they give the book to one who cannot read, saying, “Read this,” he says, “I cannot read.”

18207.text: ¶And the Lord said:/“Because this people draw near with their mouth/_and honor me with their lips,/_while their hearts are far from me,/and their fear of me is a commandment of men learned by rote;

18208.text: /therefore, behold, I will again/_do marvelous things with this people,/_wonderful and marvelous;/and the wisdom of their wise men shall perish,/_and the discernment of their discerning men shall be hid.”

18209.text: ¶Woe to those who hide deep from the Lord their counsel,/_whose deeds are in the dark,/_and who say, “Who sees us? Who knows us?”

18210.text: /You turn things upside down!/_Shall the potter be regarded as the clay;/that the thing made should say of its maker,/_“He did not make me”;/or the thing formed say of him who formed it,/_“He has no understanding”?

18211.text: §¶Is it not yet a very little while/_until Lebanon shall be turned into a fruitful field,/_and the fruitful field shall be regarded as a forest?

18212.text: /In that day the deaf shall hear/_the words of a book,/and out of their gloom and darkness/_the eyes of the blind shall see.

18213.text: /The meek shall obtain fresh joy in the Lord,/_and the poor among men shall exult in the Holy One of Israel.

18214.text: /For the ruthless shall come to nought and the scoffer cease,/_and all who watch to do evil shall be cut off,

18215.text: /who by a word make a man out to be an offender,/_and lay a snare for him who reproves in the gate,/_and with an empty plea turn aside him who is in the right.

18216.text: ¶Therefore thus says the Lord, who redeemed Abraham, concerning the house of Jacob:¶▼“Jacob shall no more be ashamed,/_no more shall his face grow pale.

18217.text: /For when he sees his children,/_the work of my hands, in his midst,/_they will sanctify my name;/they will sanctify the Holy One of Jacob,/_and will stand in awe of the God of Israel.

18218.text: /And those who err in spirit will come to understanding,/_and those who murmur will accept instruction.”

18219.text: §¶“Woe to the rebellious children,” says the Lord,/_“who carry out a plan, but not mine;/and who make a league, but not of my spirit,/_that they may add sin to sin;

18220.text: /who set out to go down to Egypt,/_without asking for my counsel,/to take refuge in the protection of Pharaoh,/_and to seek shelter in the shadow of Egypt!

18221.text: /Therefore shall the protection of Pharaoh turn to your shame,/_and the shelter in the shadow of Egypt to your humiliation.

18222.text: /For though his officials are at Zo′an/_and his envoys reach Ha′nes,

18223.text: /every one comes to shame/_through a people that cannot profit them,/that brings neither help nor profit,/_but shame and disgrace.”

18224.text: ¶An oracle on the beasts of the Negeb./Through a land of trouble and anguish,/_from where come the lioness and the lion,/_the viper and the flying serpent,/they carry their riches on the backs of asses,/_and their treasures on the humps of camels,/_to a people that cannot profit them.

18225.text: /For Egypt’s help is worthless and empty,/_therefore I have called her/_“Rahab who sits still.”

18226.text: §¶And now, go, write it before them on a tablet,/_and inscribe it in a book,/that it may be for the time to come/_as a witness for ever.

18227.text: /For they are a rebellious people,/_lying sons,/sons who will not hear/_the instruction of the Lord;

18228.text: /who say to the seers, “See not”;/_and to the prophets, “Prophesy not to us what is right;/speak to us smooth things,/_prophesy illusions,

18229.text: /leave the way, turn aside from the path,/_let us hear no more of the Holy One of Israel.”

18230.text: /Therefore thus says the Holy One of Israel,/“Because you despise this word,/_and trust in oppression and perverseness,/_and rely on them;

18231.text: /therefore this iniquity shall be to you/_like a break in a high wall, bulging out, and about to collapse,/_whose crash comes suddenly, in an instant;

18232.text: /and its breaking is like that of a potter’s vessel/_which is smashed so ruthlessly/that among its fragments not a sherd is found/_with which to take fire from the hearth,/_or to dip up water out of the cistern.”

18233.text: ¶For thus said the Lord God, the Holy One of Israel,/_“In returning and rest you shall be saved;/_in quietness and in trust shall be your strength.”/And you would not,

18234.text: /but you said,/“No! We will speed upon horses,”/_therefore you shall speed away;/and, “We will ride upon swift steeds,”/_therefore your pursuers shall be swift.

18235.text: /A thousand shall flee at the threat of one,/_at the threat of five you shall flee,/till you are left/_like a flagstaff on the top of a mountain,/_like a signal on a hill.

18236.text: §¶Therefore the Lord waits to be gracious to you;/_therefore he exalts himself to show mercy to you./For the Lord is a God of justice;/_blessed are all those who wait for him.

18237.text: ¶Yea, O people in Zion who dwell at Jerusalem; you shall weep no more. He will surely be gracious to you at the sound of your cry; when he hears it, he will answer you.

18238.text: And though the Lord give you the bread of adversity and the water of affliction, yet your Teacher will not hide himself any more, but your eyes shall see your Teacher.

18239.text: And your ears shall hear a word behind you, saying, “This is the way, walk in it,” when you turn to the right or when you turn to the left.

18240.text: Then you will defile your silver‑covered graven images and your gold‑plated molten images. You will scatter them as unclean things; you will say to them, “Begone!”

18241.text: ¶And he will give rain for the seed with which you sow the ground, and grain, the produce of the ground, which will be rich and plenteous. In that day your cattle will graze in large pastures;

18242.text: and the oxen and the asses that till the ground will eat salted provender, which has been winnowed with shovel and fork.

18243.text: And upon every lofty mountain and every high hill there will be brooks running with water, in the day of the great slaughter, when the towers fall.

18244.text: Moreover the light of the moon will be as the light of the sun, and the light of the sun will be sevenfold, as the light of seven days, in the day when the Lord binds up the hurt of his people, and heals the wounds inflicted by his blow.

18245.text: §¶Behold, the name of the Lord comes from far,/_burning with his anger, and in thick rising smoke;/his lips are full of indignation,/_and his tongue is like a devouring fire;

18246.text: /his breath is like an overflowing stream/_that reaches up to the neck;/to sift the nations with the sieve of destruction,/_and to place on the jaws of the peoples a bridle that leads astray.

18247.text: ¶You shall have a song as in the night when a holy feast is kept; and gladness of heart, as when one sets out to the sound of the flute to go to the mountain of the Lord, to the Rock of Israel.

18248.text: And the Lord will cause his majestic voice to be heard and the descending blow of his arm to be seen, in furious anger and a flame of devouring fire, with a cloudburst and tempest and hailstones.

18249.text: The Assyrians will be terror‑stricken at the voice of the Lord, when he smites with his rod.

18250.text: And every stroke of the staff of punishment which the Lord lays upon them will be to the sound of timbrels and lyres; battling with brandished arm he will fight with them.

18251.text: For a burning place has long been prepared; yea, for the king it is made ready, its pyre made deep and wide, with fire and wood in abundance; the breath of the Lord, like a stream of brimstone, kindles it.

18252.text: §¶Woe to those who go down to Egypt for help/_and rely on horses,/who trust in chariots because they are many/_and in horsemen because they are very strong,/but do not look to the Holy One of Israel/_or consult the Lord!

18253.text: /And yet he is wise and brings disaster,/_he does not call back his words,/but will arise against the house of the evildoers,/_and against the helpers of those who work iniquity.

18254.text: /The Egyptians are men, and not God;/_and their horses are flesh, and not spirit./When the Lord stretches out his hand,/_the helper will stumble, and he who is helped will fall,/_and they will all perish together.

18255.text: ¶For thus the Lord said to me,/As a lion or a young lion growls over his prey,/_and when a band of shepherds is called forth against him/is not terrified by their shouting/_or daunted at their noise,/so the Lord of hosts will come down/_to fight upon Mount Zion and upon its hill.

18256.text: /Like birds hovering, so the Lord of hosts/_will protect Jerusalem;/he will protect and deliver it,/_he will spare and rescue it.

18257.text: ¶Turn to him from whom you have deeply revolted, O people of Israel.

18258.text: For in that day every one shall cast away his idols of silver and his idols of gold, which your hands have sinfully made for you.

18259.text: ¶“And the Assyrian shall fall by a sword, not of man;/_and a sword, not of man, shall devour him;/and he shall flee from the sword,/_and his young men shall be put to forced labor.

18260.text: /His rock shall pass away in terror,/_and his officers desert the standard in panic,”/says the Lord, whose fire is in Zion,/_and whose furnace is in Jerusalem.

18261.text: §¶Behold, a king will reign in righteousness,/_and princes will rule in justice.

18262.text: /Each will be like a hiding place from the wind,/_a covert from the tempest,/like streams of water in a dry place,/_like the shade of a great rock in a weary land.

18263.text: /Then the eyes of those who see will not be closed,/_and the ears of those who hear will hearken.

18264.text: /The mind of the rash will have good judgment,/_and the tongue of the stammerers will speak readily and distinctly.

18265.text: /The fool will no more be called noble,/_nor the knave said to be honorable.

18266.text: /For the fool speaks folly,/_and his mind plots iniquity:/to practice ungodliness,/_to utter error concerning the Lord,/to leave the craving of the hungry unsatisfied,/_and to deprive the thirsty of drink.

18267.text: /The knaveries of the knave are evil;/_he devises wicked devices/to ruin the poor with lying words,/_even when the plea of the needy is right.

18268.text: /But he who is noble devises noble things,/_and by noble things he stands.

18269.text: §¶Rise up, you women who are at ease, hear my voice;/_you complacent daughters, give ear to my speech.

18270.text: /In little more than a year/_you will shudder, you complacent women;/for the vintage will fail,/_the fruit harvest will not come.

18271.text: /Tremble, you women who are at ease,/_shudder, you complacent ones;/strip, and make yourselves bare,/_and gird sackcloth upon your loins.

18272.text: /Beat upon your breasts for the pleasant fields,/_for the fruitful vine,

18273.text: /for the soil of my people/_growing up in thorns and briers;/yea, for all the joyous houses/_in the joyful city.

18274.text: /For the palace will be forsaken,/_the populous city deserted;/the hill and the watchtower/_will become dens for ever,/a joy of wild asses,/_a pasture of flocks;

18275.text: /until the Spirit is poured upon us from on high,/_and the wilderness becomes a fruitful field,/_and the fruitful field is deemed a forest.

18276.text: §¶Then justice will dwell in the wilderness,/_and righteousness abide in the fruitful field.

18277.text: /And the effect of righteousness will be peace,/_and the result of righteousness, quietness and trust for ever.

18278.text: /My people will abide in a peaceful habitation,/_in secure dwellings, and in quiet resting places.

18279.text: /And the forest will utterly go down,/_and the city will be utterly laid low.

18280.text: /Happy are you who sow beside all waters,/_who let the feet of the ox and the ass range free.

18281.text: §¶Woe to you, destroyer,/_who yourself have not been destroyed;/you treacherous one,/_with whom none has dealt treacherously!/When you have ceased to destroy,/_you will be destroyed;/and when you have made an end of dealing treacherously,/_you will be dealt with treacherously.

18282.text: ¶O Lord, be gracious to us; we wait for thee./_Be our arm every morning,/_our salvation in the time of trouble.

18283.text: /At the thunderous noise peoples flee,/_at the lifting up of thyself nations are scattered;

18284.text: /and spoil is gathered as the caterpillar gathers;/_as locusts leap, men leap upon it.

18285.text: ¶The Lord is exalted, for he dwells on high;/_he will fill Zion with justice and righteousness;

18286.text: /and he will be the stability of your times,/_abundance of salvation, wisdom, and knowledge;/_the fear of the Lord is his treasure.

18287.text: ¶Behold, the valiant ones cry without;/_the envoys of peace weep bitterly.

18288.text: /The highways lie waste,/_the wayfaring man ceases./Covenants are broken,/_witnesses are despised,/_there is no regard for man.

18289.text: /The land mourns and languishes;/_Lebanon is confounded and withers away;/Sharon is like a desert;/_and Bashan and Carmel shake off their leaves.

18290.text: ¶“Now I will arise,” says the Lord,/_“now I will lift myself up;/_now I will be exalted.

18291.text: /You conceive chaff, you bring forth stubble;/_your breath is a fire that will consume you.

18292.text: /And the peoples will be as if burned to lime,/_like thorns cut down, that are burned in the fire.”

18293.text: ¶Hear, you who are far off, what I have done;/_and you who are near, acknowledge my might.

18294.text: /The sinners in Zion are afraid;/_trembling has seized the godless:/“Who among us can dwell with the devouring fire?/_Who among us can dwell with everlasting burnings?”

18295.text: /He who walks righteously and speaks uprightly,/_who despises the gain of oppressions,/who shakes his hands, lest they hold a bribe,/_who stops his ears from hearing of bloodshed/_and shuts his eyes from looking upon evil,

18296.text: /he will dwell on the heights;/_his place of defense will be the fortresses of rocks;/_his bread will be given him, his water will be sure.

18297.text: §¶Your eyes will see the king in his beauty;/_they will behold a land that stretches afar.

18298.text: /Your mind will muse on the terror:/_“Where is he who counted, where is he who weighed the tribute?/_Where is he who counted the towers?”

18299.text: /You will see no more the insolent people,/_the people of an obscure speech which you cannot comprehend,/_stammering in a tongue which you cannot understand.

18300.text: /Look upon Zion, the city of our appointed feasts!/_Your eyes will see Jerusalem,/_a quiet habitation, an immovable tent,/whose stakes will never be plucked up,/_nor will any of its cords be broken.

18301.text: /But there the Lord in majesty will be for us/_a place of broad rivers and streams,/where no galley with oars can go,/_nor stately ship can pass.

18302.text: /For the Lord is our judge, the Lord is our ruler,/_the Lord is our king; he will save us.

18303.text: ¶Your tackle hangs loose;/_it cannot hold the mast firm in its place,/_or keep the sail spread out.¶Then prey and spoil in abundance will be divided;/_even the lame will take the prey.

18304.text: /And no inhabitant will say, “I am sick”;/_the people who dwell there will be forgiven their iniquity.

18305.text: §¶Draw near, O nations, to hear,/and hearken, O peoples!/Let the earth listen, and all that fills it;/_the world, and all that comes from it.

18306.text: /For the Lord is enraged against all the nations,/_and furious against all their host,/_he has doomed them, has given them over for slaughter.

18307.text: /Their slain shall be cast out,/_and the stench of their corpses shall rise;/_the mountains shall flow with their blood.

18308.text: /All the host of heaven shall rot away,/_and the skies roll up like a scroll./All their host shall fall,/_as leaves fall from the vine,/_like leaves falling from the fig tree.

18309.text: ¶For my sword has drunk its fill in the heavens;/_behold, it descends for judgment upon Edom,/_upon the people I have doomed.

18310.text: /The Lord has a sword; it is sated with blood,/_it is gorged with fat,/_with the blood of lambs and goats,/_with the fat of the kidneys of rams./For the Lord has a sacrifice in Bozrah,/_a great slaughter in the land of Edom.

18311.text: /Wild oxen shall fall with them,/_and young steers with the mighty bulls./Their land shall be soaked with blood,/_and their soil made rich with fat.

18312.text: ¶For the Lord has a day of vengeance,/_a year of recompense for the cause of Zion.

18313.text: /And the streams of Edom shall be turned into pitch,/_and her soil into brimstone;/_her land shall become burning pitch.

18314.text: /Night and day it shall not be quenched;/_its smoke shall go up for ever./From generation to generation it shall lie waste;/_none shall pass through it for ever and ever.

18315.text: /But the hawk and the porcupine shall possess it,/_the owl and the raven shall dwell in it./He shall stretch the line of confusion over it,/_and the plummet of chaos over its nobles.

18316.text: /They shall name it No Kingdom There,/_and all its princes shall be nothing.

18317.text: ¶Thorns shall grow over its strongholds,/_nettles and thistles in its fortresses./It shall be the haunt of jackals,/_an abode for ostriches.

18318.text: /And wild beasts shall meet with hyenas,/_the satyr shall cry to his fellow;/yea, there shall the night hag alight,/_and find for herself a resting place.

18319.text: ¶There shall the owl nest and lay/_and hatch and gather her young in her shadow;/yea, there shall the kites be gathered,/_each one with her mate.

18320.text: /Seek and read from the book of the Lord:/_Not one of these shall be missing;/_none shall be without her mate./For the mouth of the Lord has commanded,/_and his Spirit has gathered them.

18321.text: /He has cast the lot for them,/_his hand has portioned it out to them with the line;/they shall possess it for ever,/_from generation to generation they shall dwell in it.

18322.text: §¶The wilderness and the dry land shall be glad,/_the desert shall rejoice and blossom;/like the crocus

18323.text: /it shall blossom abundantly,/_and rejoice with joy and singing./The glory of Lebanon shall be given to it,/_the majesty of Carmel and Sharon./They shall see the glory of the Lord,/_the majesty of our God.

18324.text: ¶Strengthen the weak hands,/_and make firm the feeble knees.

18325.text: /Say to those who are of a fearful heart,/_“Be strong, fear not!/Behold, your God/_will come with vengeance,/with the recompense of God./_He will come and save you.”

18326.text: ¶Then the eyes of the blind shall be opened,/_and the ears of the deaf unstopped;

18327.text: /then shall the lame man leap like a hart,/_and the tongue of the dumb sing for joy./For waters shall break forth in the wilderness,/_and streams in the desert;

18328.text: /the burning sand shall become a pool,/_and the thirsty ground springs of water;/the haunt of jackals shall become a swamp,/_the grass shall become reeds and rushes.

18329.text: ¶And a highway shall be there,/_and it shall be called the Holy Way;/the unclean shall not pass over it,/_and fools shall not err therein.

18330.text: /No lion shall be there,/_nor shall any ravenous beast come up on it;/they shall not be found there,/_but the redeemed shall walk there.

18331.text: /And the ransomed of the Lord shall return,/_and come to Zion with singing;/everlasting joy shall be upon their heads;/_they shall obtain joy and gladness,/_and sorrow and sighing shall flee away.

18332.text: §¶In the fourteenth year of King Hezeki′ah, Sennach′erib king of Assyria came up against all the fortified cities of Judah and took them.

18333.text: And the king of Assyria sent the Rab′shakeh from Lachish to King Hezeki′ah at Jerusalem, with a great army. And he stood by the conduit of the upper pool on the highway to the Fuller’s Field.

18334.text: And there came out to him Eli′akim the son of Hilki′ah, who was over the household, and Shebna the secretary, and Jo′ah the son of Asaph, the recorder.

18335.text: ¶And the Rab′shakeh said to them, “Say to Hezeki′ah, ‘Thus says the great king, the king of Assyria: On what do you rest this confidence of yours?

18336.text: Do you think that mere words are strategy and power for war? On whom do you now rely, that you have rebelled against me?

18337.text: Behold, you are relying on Egypt, that broken reed of a staff, which will pierce the hand of any man who leans on it. Such is Pharaoh king of Egypt to all who rely on him.

18338.text: But if you say to me, “We rely on the Lord our God,” is it not he whose high places and altars Hezeki′ah has removed, saying to Judah and to Jerusalem,“You shall worship before this altar”?

18339.text: Come now, make a wager with my master the king of Assyria: I will give you two thousand horses, if you are able on your part to set riders upon them.

18340.text: How then can you repulse a single captain among the least of my master’s servants, when you rely on Egypt for chariots and for horsemen?

18341.text: Moreover, is it without the Lord that I have come up against this land to destroy it? The Lord said to me, Go up against this land, and destroy it.’”

18342.text: ¶Then Eli′akim, Shebna, and Jo′ah said to the Rab′shakeh, “Pray, speak to your servants in Aramaic, for we understand it; do not speak to us in the language of Judah within the hearing of the people who are on the wall.”

18343.text: But the Rab′shakeh said, “Has my master sent me to speak these words to your master and to you, and not to the men sitting on the wall, who are doomed with you to eat their own dung and drink their own urine?”

18344.text: ¶Then the Rab′shakeh stood and called out in a loud voice in the language of Judah: “Hear the words of the great king, the king of Assyria!

18345.text: Thus says the king: ‘Do not let Hezeki′ah deceive you, for he will not be able to deliver you.

18346.text: Do not let Hezeki′ah make you rely on the Lord by saying, “The Lord will surely deliver us; this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.”

18347.text: Do not listen to Hezeki′ah; for thus says the king of Assyria: Make your peace with me and come out to me; then every one of you will eat of his own vine, and every one of his own fig tree, and every one of you will drink the water of his own cistern;

18348.text: until I come and take you away to a land like your own land, a land of grain and wine, a land of bread and vineyards.

18349.text: Beware lest Hezeki′ah mislead you by saying, “The Lord will deliver us.” Has any of the gods of the nations delivered his land out of the hand of the king of Assyria?

18350.text: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharva′im? Have they delivered Samar′ia out of my hand?

18351.text: Who among all the gods of these countries have delivered their countries out of my hand, that the Lord should deliver Jerusalem out of my hand?’”

18352.text: ¶But they were silent and answered him not a word, for the king’s command was, “Do not answer him.”

18353.text: Then Eli′akim the son of Hilki′ah, who was over the household, and Shebna the secretary, and Jo′ah the son of Asaph, the recorder, came to Hezeki′ah with their clothes rent, and told him the words of the Rab′shakeh.

18354.text: §¶When King Hezeki′ah heard it, he rent his clothes, and covered himself with sackcloth, and went into the house of the Lord.

18355.text: And he sent Eli′akim, who was over the household, and Shebna the secretary, and the senior priests, clothed with sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah the son of Amoz.

18356.text: They said to him, “Thus says Hezeki′ah, ‘This day is a day of distress, of rebuke, and of disgrace; children have come to the birth, and there is no strength to bring them forth.

18357.text: It may be that the Lord your God heard the words of the Rab′shakeh, whom his master the king of Assyria has sent to mock the living God, and will rebuke the words which the Lord your God has heard; therefore lift up your prayer for the remnant that is left.’”

18358.text: ¶When the servants of King Hezeki′ah came to Isaiah,

18359.text: Isaiah said to them, “Say to your master, ‘Thus says the Lord: Do not be afraid because of the words that you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have reviled me.

18360.text: Behold, I will put a spirit in him, so that he shall hear a rumor, and return to his own land; and I will make him fall by the sword in his own land.’”

18361.text: ¶The Rab′shakeh returned, and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah; for he had heard that the king had left Lachish.

18362.text: Now the king heard concerning Tirha′kah king of Ethiopia, “He has set out to fight against you.” And when he heard it, he sent messengers to Hezeki′ah, saying,

18363.text: “Thus shall you speak to Hezeki′ah king of Judah: ‘Do not let your God on whom you rely deceive you by promising that Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.

18364.text: Behold, you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all lands, destroying them utterly. And shall you be delivered?

18365.text: Have the gods of the nations delivered them, the nations which my fathers destroyed, Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the people of Eden who were in Tel‑assar?

18366.text: Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sepharva′im, the king of Hena, or the king of Ivvah?’”

18367.text: §¶Hezeki′ah received the letter from the hand of the messengers, and read it; and Hezeki′ah went up to the house of the Lord, and spread it before the Lord.

18368.text: And Hezeki′ah prayed to the Lord:

18369.text: “O Lord of hosts, God of Israel, who art enthroned above the cherubim, thou art the God, thou alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth; thou hast made heaven and earth.

18370.text: Incline thy ear, O Lord, and hear; open thy eyes, O Lord, and see; and hear all the words of Sennach′erib, which he has sent to mock the living God.

18371.text: Of a truth, O Lord, the kings of Assyria have laid waste all the nations and their lands,

18372.text: and have cast their gods into the fire; for they were no gods, but the work of men’s hands, wood and stone; therefore they were destroyed.

18373.text: So now, O Lord our God, save us from his hand, that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that thou alone art the Lord.”

18374.text: ¶Then Isaiah the son of Amoz sent to Hezeki′ah, saying, “Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: Because you have prayed to me concerning Sennach′erib king of Assyria,

18375.text: this is the word that the Lord has spoken concerning him:¶▼‘She despises you, she scorns you—/_the virgin daughter of Zion;/she wags her head behind you—/_the daughter of Jerusalem.

18376.text: ¶‘Whom have you mocked and reviled?/_Against whom have you raised your voice/and haughtily lifted your eyes?/_Against the Holy One of Israel!

18377.text: /By your servants you have mocked the Lord,/_and you have said, With my many chariots/I have gone up the heights of the mountains,/_to the far recesses of Lebanon;/I felled its tallest cedars,/_its choicest cypresses;/I came to its remotest height,/_its densest forest.

18378.text: /I dug wells/_and drank waters,/and I dried up with the sole of my foot/_all the streams of Egypt.

18379.text: ¶‘Have you not heard/_that I determined it long ago?/I planned from days of old/_what now I bring to pass,/that you should make fortified cities/_crash into heaps of ruins,

18380.text: /while their inhabitants, shorn of strength,/_are dismayed and confounded,/and have become like plants of the field/_and like tender grass,/like grass on the housetops,/_blighted before it is grown.

18381.text: ¶‘I know your sitting down/_and your going out and coming in,/_and your raging against me.

18382.text: /Because you have raged against me/_and your arrogance has come to my ears,/I will put my hook in your nose/_and my bit in your mouth,/and I will turn you back on the way/_by which you came.’

18383.text: ¶“And this shall be the sign for you: this year eat what grows of itself, and in the second year what springs of the same; then in the third year sow and reap, and plant vineyards, and eat their fruit.

18384.text: And the surviving remnant of the house of Judah shall again take root downward, and bear fruit upward;

18385.text: for out of Jerusalem shall go forth a remnant, and out of Mount Zion a band of survivors. The zeal of the Lord of hosts will accomplish this.

18386.text: ¶“Therefore thus says the Lord concerning the king of Assyria: He shall not come into this city, or shoot an arrow there, or come before it with a shield, or cast up a siege mound against it.

18387.text: By the way that he came, by the same he shall return, and he shall not come into this city, says the Lord.

18388.text: For I will defend this city to save it, for my own sake and for the sake of my servant David.”

18389.text: §¶And the angel of the Lord went forth, and slew a hundred and eighty‑five thousand in the camp of the Assyrians; and when men arose early in the morning, behold, these were all dead bodies.

18390.text: Then Sennach′erib king of Assyria departed, and went home and dwelt at Nin′eveh.

18391.text: And as he was worshiping in the house of Nisroch his god, Adram′melech and Share′zer, his sons, slew him with the sword, and escaped into the land of Ar′arat. And E′sar‑had′don his son reigned in his stead.

18392.text: §¶In those days Hezeki′ah became sick and was at the point of death. And Isaiah the prophet the son of Amoz came to him, and said to him, “Thus says the Lord: Set your house in order; for you shall die, you shall not recover.”

18393.text: Then Hezeki′ah turned his face to the wall, and prayed to the Lord,

18394.text: and said, “Remember now, O Lord, I beseech thee, how I have walked before thee in faithfulness and with a whole heart, and have done what is good in thy sight.” And Hezeki′ah wept bitterly.

18395.text: Then the word of the Lord came to Isaiah:

18396.text: “Go and say to Hezeki′ah, Thus says the Lord, the God of David your father: I have heard your prayer, I have seen your tears; behold, I will add fifteen years to your life.

18397.text: I will deliver you and this city out of the hand of the king of Assyria, and defend this city.

18398.text: ¶“This is the sign to you from the Lord, that the Lord will do this thing that he has promised:

18399.text: Behold, I will make the shadow cast by the declining sun on the dial of Ahaz turn back ten steps.” So the sun turned back on the dial the ten steps by which it had declined.

18400.text: ¶A writing of Hezeki′ah king of Judah, after he had been sick and had recovered from his sickness:

18401.text: ¶I said, In the noontide of my days/_I must depart;/I am consigned to the gates of Sheol/_for the rest of my years.

18402.text: /I said, I shall not see the Lord/_in the land of the living;/I shall look upon man no more/_among the inhabitants of the world.

18403.text: /My dwelling is plucked up and removed from me/_like a shepherd’s tent;/like a weaver I have rolled up my life;/_he cuts me off from the loom;/from day to night thou dost bring me to an end;

18404.text: /_I cry for help until morning;/like a lion he breaks all my bones;/_from day to night thou dost bring me to an end.

18405.text: ¶Like a swallow or a crane I clamor,/_I moan like a dove./My eyes are weary with looking upward./_O Lord, I am oppressed; be thou my security!

18406.text: /But what can I say? For he has spoken to me,/_and he himself has done it./All my sleep has fled/_because of the bitterness of my soul.

18407.text: ¶O Lord, by these things men live,/_and in all these is the life of my spirit./_Oh, restore me to health and make me live!

18408.text: /Lo, it was for my welfare/_that I had great bitterness;/but thou hast held back my life/_from the pit of destruction,/for thou hast cast all my sins/_behind thy back.

18409.text: /For Sheol cannot thank thee,/_death cannot praise thee;/those who go down to the pit cannot hope/_for thy faithfulness.

18410.text: /The living, the living, he thanks thee,/_as I do this day;/the father makes known to the children/_thy faithfulness.

18411.text: ¶The Lord will save me,/_and we will sing to stringed instruments/all the days of our life,/_at the house of the Lord.

18412.text: ¶Now Isaiah had said, “Let them take a cake of figs, and apply it to the boil, that he may recover.”

18413.text: Hezeki′ah also had said, “What is the sign that I shall go up to the house of the Lord?”

18414.text: §¶At that time Mero′dach‑bal′adan the son of Bal′adan, king of Babylon, sent envoys with letters and a present to Hezeki′ah, for he heard that he had been sick and had recovered.

18415.text: And Hezeki′ah welcomed them; and he showed them his treasure house, the silver, the gold, the spices, the precious oil, his whole armory, all that was found in his storehouses. There was nothing in his house or in all his realm that Hezeki′ah did not show them.

18416.text: Then Isaiah the prophet came to King Hezeki′ah, and said to him, “What did these men say? And whence did they come to you?” Hezeki′ah said, “They have come to me from a far country, from Babylon.”

18417.text: He said, “What have they seen in your house?” Hezeki′ah answered, “They have seen all that is in my house; there is nothing in my storehouses that I did not show them.”

18418.text: ¶Then Isaiah said to Hezeki′ah, “Hear the word of the Lord of hosts:

18419.text: Behold, the days are coming, when all that is in your house, and that which your fathers have stored up till this day, shall be carried to Babylon; nothing shall be left, says the Lord.

18420.text: And some of your own sons, who are born to you, shall be taken away; and they shall be eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.”

18421.text: Then said Hezeki′ah to Isaiah, “The word of the Lord which you have spoken is good.” For he thought, “There will be peace and security in my days.”

18423.text: /Speak tenderly to Jerusalem,/_and cry to her/that her warfare is ended,/_that her iniquity is pardoned,/that she has received from the Lord’s hand/_double for all her sins.

18424.text: ¶A voice cries:/“In the wilderness prepare the way of the Lord,/_Make straight in the desert a highway for our God.

18425.text: /Every valley shall be lifted up,/_and every mountain and hill be made low;/the uneven ground shall become level,/_and the rough places a plain.

18426.text: /And the glory of the Lord shall be revealed,/_and all flesh shall see it together,/_for the mouth of the Lord has spoken.”

18427.text: ¶A voice says, “Cry!”/_And I said, “What shall I cry?”/All flesh is grass,/_and all its beauty is like the flower of the field.

18428.text: /The grass withers, the flower fades,/_when the breath of the Lord blows upon it;/_surely the people is grass.

18429.text: /The grass withers, the flower fades;/_but the word of our God will stand for ever.

18430.text: ¶Get you up to a high mountain,/_O Zion, herald of good tidings;/lift up your voice with strength,/_O Jerusalem, herald of good tidings,/_lift it up, fear not;/say to the cities of Judah,/_“Behold your God!”

18431.text: /Behold, the Lord God comes with might,/_and his arm rules for him;/behold, his reward is with him,/_and his recompense before him.

18432.text: /He will feed his flock like a shepherd,/_he will gather the lambs in his arms,/he will carry them in his bosom,/_and gently lead those that are with young.

18433.text: ¶Who has measured the waters in the hollow of his hand/_and marked off the heavens with a span,/enclosed the dust of the earth in a measure/_and weighed the mountains in scales/_and the hills in a balance?

18434.text: /Who has directed the Spirit of the Lord,/_or as his counselor has instructed him?

18435.text: /Whom did he consult for his enlightenment,/_and who taught him the path of justice,/and taught him knowledge,/_and showed him the way of understanding?

18436.text: /Behold, the nations are like a drop from a bucket,/_and are accounted as the dust on the scales;/_behold, he takes up the isles like fine dust.

18437.text: /Lebanon would not suffice for fuel,/_nor are its beasts enough for a burnt offering.

18438.text: /All the nations are as nothing before him,/_they are accounted by him as less than nothing and emptiness.

18439.text: ¶To whom then will you liken God,/_or what likeness compare with him?

18440.text: /The idol! a workman casts it,/_and a goldsmith overlays it with gold,/_and casts for it silver chains.

18441.text: /He who is impoverished chooses for an offering/_wood that will not rot;/he seeks out a skilful craftsman/_to set up an image that will not move.

18442.text: ¶Have you not known? Have you not heard?/_Has it not been told you from the beginning?/_Have you not understood from the foundations of the earth?

18443.text: /It is he who sits above the circle of the earth,/_and its inhabitants are like grasshoppers;/who stretches out the heavens like a curtain,/_and spreads them like a tent to dwell in;

18444.text: /who brings princes to nought,/_and makes the rulers of the earth as nothing.

18445.text: ¶Scarcely are they planted, scarcely sown,/_scarcely has their stem taken root in the earth,/when he blows upon them, and they wither,/_and the tempest carries them off like stubble.

18446.text: ¶To whom then will you compare me,/_that I should be like him? says the Holy One.

18447.text: /Lift up your eyes on high and see:/_who created these?/He who brings out their host by number,/_calling them all by name;/by the greatness of his might,/_and because he is strong in power/_not one is missing.

18448.text: ¶Why do you say, O Jacob,/_and speak, O Israel,/“My way is hid from the Lord,/_and my right is disregarded by my God”?

18449.text: /Have you not known? Have you not heard?/The Lord is the everlasting God,/_the Creator of the ends of the earth./He does not faint or grow weary,/_his understanding is unsearchable.

18450.text: /He gives power to the faint,/_and to him who has no might he increases strength.

18451.text: /Even youths shall faint and be weary,/_and young men shall fall exhausted;

18452.text: /but they who wait for the Lord shall renew their strength,/_they shall mount up with wings like eagles,/they shall run and not be weary,/_they shall walk and not faint.

18453.text: §¶Listen to me in silence, O coastlands;/_let the peoples renew their strength;/let them approach, then let them speak;/_let us together draw near for judgment.

18454.text: ¶Who stirred up one from the east/_whom victory meets at every step?/He gives up nations before him,/_so that he tramples kings under foot;/he makes them like dust with his sword,/_like driven stubble with his bow.

18455.text: /He pursues them and passes on safely,/_by paths his feet have not trod.

18456.text: /Who has performed and done this,/_calling the generations from the beginning?/I, the Lord, the first,/_and with the last; I am He.

18457.text: ¶The coastlands have seen and are afraid,/_the ends of the earth tremble;/_they have drawn near and come.

18458.text: /Every one helps his neighbor,/_and says to his brother, “Take courage!”

18459.text: /The craftsman encourages the goldsmith,/_and he who smooths with the hammer him who strikes the anvil,/saying of the soldering, “It is good”;/_and they fasten it with nails so that it cannot be moved.

18460.text: ¶But you, Israel, my servant,/_Jacob, whom I have chosen,/_the offspring of Abraham, my friend;

18461.text: /you whom I took from the ends of the earth,/_and called from its farthest corners,/saying to you, “You are my servant,/_I have chosen you and not cast you off”;

18462.text: /fear not, for I am with you,/_be not dismayed, for I am your God;/I will strengthen you, I will help you,/_I will uphold you with my victorious right hand.

18463.text: ¶Behold, all who are incensed against you/_shall be put to shame and confounded;/those who strive against you/_shall be as nothing and shall perish.

18464.text: /You shall seek those who contend with you,/_but you shall not find them;/those who war against you/_shall be as nothing at all.

18465.text: /For I, the Lord your God,/_hold your right hand;/it is I who say to you, “Fear not,/_I will help you.”

18466.text: ¶Fear not, you worm Jacob,/_you men of Israel!/I will help you, says the Lord;/_your Redeemer is the Holy One of Israel.

18467.text: /Behold, I will make of you a threshing sledge,/_new, sharp, and having teeth;/you shall thresh the mountains and crush them,/_and you shall make the hills like chaff;

18468.text: /you shall winnow them and the wind shall carry them away,/_and the tempest shall scatter them./And you shall rejoice in the Lord;/_in the Holy One of Israel you shall glory.

18469.text: ¶When the poor and needy seek water,/_and there is none,/_and their tongue is parched with thirst,/I the Lord will answer them,/_I the God of Israel will not forsake them.

18470.text: /I will open rivers on the bare heights,/_and fountains in the midst of the valleys;/I will make the wilderness a pool of water,/_and the dry land springs of water.

18471.text: /I will put in the wilderness the cedar,/_the acacia, the myrtle, and the olive;/I will set in the desert the cypress,/_the plane and the pine together;

18472.text: /that men may see and know,/_may consider and understand together,/that the hand of the Lord has done this,/_the Holy One of Israel has created it.

18473.text: §¶Set forth your case, says the Lord;/_bring your proofs, says the King of Jacob.

18474.text: /Let them bring them, and tell us what is to happen./Tell us the former things, what they are,/_that we may consider them,/that we may know their outcome;/_or declare to us the things to come.

18475.text: /Tell us what is to come hereafter,/_that we may know that you are gods;/do good, or do harm,/_that we may be dismayed and terrified.

18476.text: /Behold, you are nothing,/_and your work is nought;/_an abomination is he who chooses you.

18477.text: ¶I stirred up one from the north, and he has come,/_from the rising of the sun, and he shall call on my name;/he shall trample on rulers as on mortar,/_as the potter treads clay.

18478.text: /Who declared it from the beginning, that we might know,/_and beforetime, that we might say, “He is right”?/There was none who declared it, none who proclaimed,/_none who heard your words.

18479.text: /I first have declared it to Zion,/_and I give to Jerusalem a herald of good tidings.

18480.text: /But when I look there is no one;/_among these there is no counselor/_who, when I ask, gives an answer.

18481.text: /Behold, they are all a delusion;/_their works are nothing;/_their molten images are empty wind.

18482.text: §¶Behold my servant, whom I uphold,/_my chosen, in whom my soul delights;/I have put my Spirit upon him,/_he will bring forth justice to the nations.

18483.text: /He will not cry or lift up his voice,/_or make it heard in the street;

18484.text: /a bruised reed he will not break,/_and a dimly burning wick he will not quench;/_he will faithfully bring forth justice.

18485.text: /He will not fail or be discouraged/_till he has established justice in the earth;/_and the coastlands wait for his law.

18486.text: ¶Thus says God, the Lord,/_who created the heavens and stretched them out,/_who spread forth the earth and what comes from it,/who gives breath to the people upon it/_and spirit to those who walk in it:

18487.text: /“I am the Lord, I have called you in righteousness,/_I have taken you by the hand and kept you;/I have given you as a covenant to the people,/_a light to the nations,

18488.text: /_to open the eyes that are blind,/to bring out the prisoners from the dungeon,/_from the prison those who sit in darkness.

18489.text: /I am the Lord, that is my name;/_my glory I give to no other,/_nor my praise to graven images.

18490.text: /Behold, the former things have come to pass,/_and new things I now declare;/before they spring forth/_I tell you of them.”

18491.text: §¶Sing to the Lord a new song,/_his praise from the end of the earth!/Let the sea roar and all that fills it,/_the coastlands and their inhabitants.

18492.text: /Let the desert and its cities lift up their voice,/_the villages that Kedar inhabits;/let the inhabitants of Sela sing for joy,/_let them shout from the top of the mountains.

18493.text: /Let them give glory to the Lord,/_and declare his praise in the coastlands.

18494.text: /The Lord goes forth like a mighty man,/_like a man of war he stirs up his fury;/he cries out, he shouts aloud,/_he shows himself mighty against his foes.

18495.text: ¶For a long time I have held my peace,/_I have kept still and restrained myself;/now I will cry out like a woman in travail,/_I will gasp and pant.

18496.text: /I will lay waste mountains and hills,/_and dry up all their herbage;/I will turn the rivers into islands,/_and dry up the pools.

18497.text: /And I will lead the blind/_in a way that they know not,/in paths that they have not known/_I will guide them./I will turn the darkness before them into light,/_the rough places into level ground./These are the things I will do,/_and I will not forsake them.

18498.text: /They shall be turned back and utterly put to shame,/_who trust in graven images,/who say to molten images,/_“You are our gods.”

18499.text: ¶Hear, you deaf;/_and look, you blind, that you may see!

18500.text: /Who is blind but my servant,/_or deaf as my messenger whom I send?/Who is blind as my dedicated one,/_or blind as the servant of the Lord?

18501.text: /He sees many things, but does not observe them;/_his ears are open, but he does not hear.

18502.text: §¶The Lord was pleased, for his righteousness’ sake,/_to magnify his law and make it glorious.

18503.text: /But this is a people robbed and plundered,/_they are all of them trapped in holes/_and hidden in prisons;/they have become a prey with none to rescue,/_a spoil with none to say, “Restore!”

18504.text: /Who among you will give ear to this,/_will attend and listen for the time to come?

18505.text: /Who gave up Jacob to the spoiler,/_and Israel to the robbers?/Was it not the Lord, against whom we have sinned,/_in whose ways they would not walk,/_and whose law they would not obey?

18506.text: /So he poured upon him the heat of his anger/_and the might of battle;/it set him on fire round about, but he did not understand;/_it burned him, but he did not take it to heart.

18507.text: §¶But now thus says the Lord,/he who created you, O Jacob,/_he who formed you, O Israel:/“Fear not, for I have redeemed you;/_I have called you by name, you are mine.

18508.text: /When you pass through the waters I will be with you;/_and through the rivers, they shall not overwhelm you;/when you walk through fire you shall not be burned,/_and the flame shall not consume you.

18509.text: /For I am the Lord your God,/_the Holy One of Israel, your Savior./I give Egypt as your ransom,/_Ethiopia and Seba in exchange for you.

18510.text: /Because you are precious in my eyes,/_and honored, and I love you,/I give men in return for you,/_peoples in exchange for your life.

18511.text: /Fear not, for I am with you;/_I will bring your offspring from the east,/_and from the west I will gather you;

18512.text: /I will say to the north, Give up,/_and to the south, Do not withhold;/bring my sons from afar/_and my daughters from the end of the earth,

18513.text: /every one who is called by my name,/_whom I created for my glory,/_whom I formed and made.”

18514.text: ¶Bring forth the people who are blind, yet have eyes,/_who are deaf, yet have ears!

18515.text: /Let all the nations gather together,/_and let the peoples assemble./Who among them can declare this,/_and show us the former things?/Let them bring their witnesses to justify them,/_and let them hear and say, It is true.

18516.text: /“You are my witnesses,” says the Lord,/_“and my servant whom I have chosen,/that you may know and believe me/_and understand that I am He./Before me no god was formed,/_nor shall there be any after me.

18517.text: /I, I am the Lord,/_and besides me there is no savior.

18518.text: /I declared and saved and proclaimed,/_when there was no strange god among you;/_and you are my witnesses,” says the Lord.

18519.text: /“I am God, and also henceforth I am He;/_there is none who can deliver from my hand;/_I work and who can hinder it?”

18520.text: ¶Thus says the Lord,/_your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel:/“For your sake I will send to Babylon/_and break down all the bars,/_and the shouting of the Chalde′ans will be turned to lamentations.

18521.text: /I am the Lord, your Holy One,/_the Creator of Israel, your King.”

18522.text: /Thus says the Lord,/_who makes a way in the sea,/_a path in the mighty waters,

18523.text: /who brings forth chariot and horse,/_army and warrior;/they lie down, they cannot rise,/_they are extinguished, quenched like a wick:

18524.text: /“Remember not the former things,/_nor consider the things of old.

18525.text: /Behold, I am doing a new thing;/_now it springs forth, do you not perceive it?/I will make a way in the wilderness/_and rivers in the desert.

18526.text: /The wild beasts will honor me,/_the jackals and the ostriches;/for I give water in the wilderness,/_rivers in the desert,/to give drink to my chosen people,

18527.text: /_the people whom I formed for myself/that they might declare my praise.

18528.text: ¶“Yet you did not call upon me, O Jacob;/_but you have been weary of me, O Israel!

18529.text: /You have not brought me your sheep for burnt offerings,/_or honored me with your sacrifices./I have not burdened you with offerings,/_or wearied you with frankincense.

18530.text: /You have not bought me sweet cane with money,/_or satisfied me with the fat of your sacrifices./But you have burdened me with your sins,/_you have wearied me with your iniquities.

18531.text: ¶“I, I am He/_who blots out your transgressions for my own sake,/_and I will not remember your sins.

18532.text: /Put me in remembrance, let us argue together;/_set forth your case, that you may be proved right.

18533.text: /Your first father sinned,/_and your mediators transgressed against me.

18534.text: /Therefore I profaned the princes of the sanctuary,/_I delivered Jacob to utter destruction/_and Israel to reviling.

18535.text: §¶“But now hear, O Jacob my servant,/_Israel whom I have chosen!

18536.text: /Thus says the Lord who made you,/_who formed you from the womb and will help you:/Fear not, O Jacob my servant,/_Jesh′urun whom I have chosen.

18537.text: /For I will pour water on the thirsty land,/_and streams on the dry ground;/I will pour my Spirit upon your descendants,/_and my blessing on your offspring.

18538.text: /They shall spring up like grass amid waters,/_like willows by flowing streams.

18539.text: /This one will say, ‘I am the Lord’s,’/_another will call himself by the name of Jacob,/and another will write on his hand, ‘The Lord’s,’/_and surname himself by the name of Israel.”

18540.text: ¶Thus says the Lord, the King of Israel/_and his Redeemer, the Lord of hosts:/“I am the first and I am the last;/_besides me there is no god.

18541.text: /Who is like me? Let him proclaim it,/_let him declare and set it forth before me./Who has announced from of old the things to come?/_Let them tell us what is yet to be.

18542.text: /Fear not, nor be afraid;/_have I not told you from of old and declared it?/_And you are my witnesses!/Is there a God besides me?/_There is no Rock; I know not any.”

18543.text: §¶All who make idols are nothing, and the things they delight in do not profit; their witnesses neither see nor know, that they may be put to shame.

18544.text: Who fashions a god or casts an image, that is profitable for nothing?

18545.text: Behold, all his fellows shall be put to shame, and the craftsmen are but men; let them all assemble, let them stand forth, they shall be terrified, they shall be put to shame together.

18546.text: ¶The ironsmith fashions it and works it over the coals; he shapes it with hammers, and forges it with his strong arm; he becomes hungry and his strength fails, he drinks no water and is faint.

18547.text: The carpenter stretches a line, he marks it out with a pencil; he fashions it with planes, and marks it with a compass; he shapes it into the figure of a man, with the beauty of a man, to dwell in a house.

18548.text: He cuts down cedars; or he chooses a holm tree or an oak and lets it grow strong among the trees of the forest; he plants a cedar and the rain nourishes it.

18549.text: Then it becomes fuel for a man; he takes a part of it and warms himself, he kindles a fire and bakes bread; also he makes a god and worships it, he makes it a graven image and falls down before it.

18550.text: Half of it he burns in the fire; over the half he eats flesh, he roasts meat and is satisfied; also he warms himself and says, “Aha, I am warm, I have seen the fire!”

18551.text: And the rest of it he makes into a god, his idol; and falls down to it and worships it; he prays to it and says, “Deliver me, for thou art my god!”

18552.text: ¶They know not, nor do they discern; for he has shut their eyes, so that they cannot see, and their minds, so that they cannot understand.

18553.text: No one considers, nor is there knowledge or discernment to say, “Half of it I burned in the fire, I also baked bread on its coals, I roasted flesh and have eaten; and shall I make the residue of it an abomination? Shall I fall down before a block of wood?”

18554.text: He feeds on ashes; a deluded mind has led him astray, and he cannot deliver himself or say, “Is there not a lie in my right hand?”

18555.text: §¶Remember these things, O Jacob,/_and Israel, for you are my servant;/I formed you, you are my servant;/_O Israel, you will not be forgotten by me.

18556.text: /I have swept away your transgressions like a cloud,/_and your sins like mist;/return to me, for I have redeemed you.

18557.text: ¶Sing, O heavens, for the Lord has done it;/_shout, O depths of the earth;/break forth into singing, O mountains,/_O forest, and every tree in it!/For the Lord has redeemed Jacob,/_and will be glorified in Israel.

18558.text: ¶Thus says the Lord, your Redeemer,/_who formed you from the womb:/“I am the Lord, who made all things,/_who stretched out the heavens alone,/_who spread out the earth—Who was with me?—

18559.text: /who frustrates the omens of liars,/_and makes fools of diviners;/who turns wise men back,/_and makes their knowledge foolish;

18560.text: /who confirms the word of his servant,/_and performs the counsel of his messengers;/who says of Jerusalem, ‘She shall be inhabited,’/_and of the cities of Judah, ‘They shall be built,/_and I will raise up their ruins’;

18561.text: /who says to the deep, ‘Be dry,/_I will dry up your rivers’;

18562.text: /who says of Cyrus, ‘He is my shepherd,/_and he shall fulfil all my purpose’;/saying of Jerusalem. ‘She shall be built,’/_and of the temple, ‘Your foundation shall be laid.’”

18563.text: §¶Thus says the Lord to his anointed, to Cyrus,/_whose right hand I have grasped,/to subdue nations before him/_and ungird the loins of kings,/to open doors before him/_that gates may not be closed:

18564.text: /“I will go before you/_and level the mountains,/I will break in pieces the doors of bronze/_and cut asunder the bars of iron,

18565.text: /I will give you the treasures of darkness/_and the hoards in secret places,/that you may know that it is I, the Lord,/_the God of Israel, who call you by your name.

18566.text: /For the sake of my servant Jacob,/_and Israel my chosen,/I call you by your name,/_I surname you, though you do not know me.

18567.text: /I am the Lord, and there is no other,/_besides me there is no God;/_I gird you, though you do not know me,

18568.text: /that men may know, from the rising of the sun/_and from the west, that there is none besides me;/_I am the Lord, and there is no other.

18569.text: /I form light and create darkness,/_I make weal and create woe,/_I am the Lord, who do all these things.

18570.text: ¶“Shower, O heavens, from above,/_and let the skies rain down righteousness;/let the earth open, that salvation may sprout forth,/_and let it cause righteousness to spring up also;/_I the Lord have created it.

18571.text: ¶“Woe to him who strives with his Maker,/_an earthen vessel with the potter!/Does the clay say to him who fashions it, ‘What are you making?’/_or ‘Your work has no handles’?

18572.text: /Woe to him who says to a father, ‘What are you begetting?’/_or to a woman, ‘With what are you in travail?’”

18573.text: /Thus says the Lord,/_the Holy One of Israel, and his Maker:/“Will you question me about my children,/_or command me concerning the work of my hands?

18574.text: /I made the earth,/_and created man upon it;/it was my hands that stretched out the heavens,/_and I commanded all their host.

18575.text: /I have aroused him in righteousness,/_and I will make straight all his ways;/he shall build my city/_and set my exiles free,/not for price or reward,”/_says the Lord of hosts.

18576.text: ¶Thus says the Lord:/“The wealth of Egypt and the merchandise of Ethiopia,/_and the Sabe′ans, men of stature,/shall come over to you and be yours,/_they shall follow you;/_they shall come over in chains and bow down to you./They will make supplication to you, saying:/_‘God is with you only, and there is no other,/_no god besides him.’”

18577.text: /Truly, thou art a God who hidest thyself,/_O God of Israel, the Savior.

18578.text: /All of them are put to shame and confounded,/_the makers of idols go in confusion together.

18579.text: /But Israel is saved by the Lord/_with everlasting salvation;/you shall not be put to shame or confounded/_to all eternity.

18580.text: ¶For thus says the Lord,/who created the heavens/_(he is God!),/who formed the earth and made it/_(he established it;/he did not create it a chaos,/_he formed it to be inhabited!):/“I am the Lord, and there is no other.

18581.text: /I did not speak in secret,/_in a land of darkness;/I did not say to the offspring of Jacob,/_‘Seek me in chaos.’/I the Lord speak the truth,/_I declare what is right.

18582.text: §¶“Assemble yourselves and come,/_draw near together,/_you survivors of the nations!/They have no knowledge/_who carry about their wooden idols,/and keep on praying to a god/_that cannot save.

18583.text: /Declare and present your case;/_let them take counsel together!/Who told this long ago?/_Who declared it of old?/Was it not I, the Lord?/_And there is no other god besides me,/a righteous God and a Savior;/_there is none besides me.

18584.text: ¶“Turn to me and be saved,/_all the ends of the earth!/_For I am God, and there is no other.

18585.text: /By myself I have sworn,/_from my mouth has gone forth in righteousness/_a word that shall not return:/‘To me every knee shall bow,/_every tongue shall swear.’

18586.text: ¶“Only in the Lord, it shall be said of me,/_are righteousness and strength;/to him shall come and be ashamed,/_all who were incensed against him.

18587.text: /In the Lord all the offspring of Israel/_shall triumph and glory.”

18588.text: ¶Bel bows down, Nebo stoops,/their idols are on beasts and cattle;/these things you carry are loaded/_as burdens on weary beasts.

18589.text: /They stoop, they bow down together,/_they cannot save the burden,/_but themselves go into captivity.

18590.text: ¶“Hearken to me, O house of Jacob,/_all the remnant of the house of Israel,/who have been borne by me from your birth,/_carried from the womb;

18591.text: /even to your old age I am He,/_and to gray hairs I will carry you./I have made, and I will bear;/_I will carry and will save.

18592.text: ¶“To whom will you liken me and make me equal,/_and compare me, that we may be alike?

18593.text: /Those who lavish gold from the purse,/_and weigh out silver in the scales,/hire a goldsmith, and he makes it into a god;/_then they fall down and worship!

18594.text: /They lift it upon their shoulders, they carry it,/_they set it in its place, and its stands there;/_it cannot move from its place./If one cries to it, it does not answer/_or save him from his trouble.

18595.text: ¶“Remember this and consider,/_recall it to mind, you transgressors,

18596.text: /_remember the former things of old;/for I am God, and there is no other;/_I am God, and there is none like me,

18597.text: /declaring the end from the beginning/_and from ancient times things not yet done,/saying, ‘My counsel shall stand,/_and I will accomplish all my purpose,’

18598.text: /calling a bird of prey from the east,/_the man of my counsel from a far country./I have spoken, and I will bring it to pass;/_I have purposed, and I will do it.

18599.text: ¶“Hearken to me, you stubborn of heart,/_you who are far from deliverance:

18600.text: /I bring near my deliverance, it is not far off,/_and my salvation will not tarry;/I will put salvation in Zion,/_for Israel my glory.”

18601.text: §¶Come down and sit in the dust,/O virgin daughter of Babylon;/sit on the ground without a throne,/_O daughter of the Chalde′ans!/For you shall no more be called/_tender and delicate.

18602.text: /Take the millstones and grind meal,/_put off your veil,/strip off your robe, uncover your legs,/_pass through the rivers.

18603.text: /Your nakedness shall be uncovered,/_and your shame shall be seen./I will take vengeance,/_and I will spare no man.

18604.text: /Our Redeemer—the Lord of hosts is his name—/_is the Holy One of Israel.

18605.text: ¶Sit in silence, and go into darkness,/_O daughter of the Chalde′ans;/for you shall no more be called/_the mistress of kingdoms.

18606.text: /I was angry with my people,/_I profaned my heritage;/I gave them into your hand,/_you showed them no mercy;/on the aged you made your yoke/_exceedingly heavy.

18607.text: /You said, “I shall be mistress for ever,”/_so that you did not lay these things to heart/_or remember their end.

18608.text: ¶Now therefore hear this, you lover of pleasures,/_who sit securely,/who say in your heart,/_“I am, and there is no one besides me;/I shall not sit as a widow/_or know the loss of children”:

18609.text: /These two things shall come to you/_in a moment, in one day;/the loss of children and widowhood/_shall come upon you in full measure,/in spite of your many sorceries/_and the great power of your enchantments.

18610.text: ¶You felt secure in your wickedness,/_you said, “No one sees me”;/your wisdom and your knowledge/_led you astray,/and you said in your heart,/_“I am, and there is no one besides me.”

18611.text: /But evil shall come upon you,/_for which you cannot atone;/disaster shall fall upon you,/_which you will not be able to expiate;/and ruin shall come on you suddenly,/_of which you know nothing.

18612.text: ¶Stand fast in your enchantments/_and your many sorceries,/_with which you have labored from your youth;/perhaps you may be able to succeed,/_perhaps you may inspire terror.

18613.text: /You are wearied with your many counsels;/_let them stand forth and save you,/those who divide the heavens,/_who gaze at the stars,/who at the new moons predict/_what shall befall you.

18614.text: ¶Behold, they are like stubble,/_the fire consumes them;/they cannot deliver themselves/_from the power of the flame./No coal for warming oneself is this,/_no fire to sit before!

18615.text: /Such to you are those with whom you have labored,/_who have trafficked with you from your youth;/they wander about each in his own direction;/_there is no one to save you.

18616.text: §¶Hear this, O house of Jacob,/who are called by the name of Israel,/_and who came forth from the loins of Judah;/who swear by the name of the Lord,/_and confess the God of Israel,/_but not in truth or right.

18617.text: /For they call themselves after the holy city,/_and stay themselves on the God of Israel;/_the Lord of hosts is his name.

18618.text: ¶“The former things I declared of old,/_they went forth from my mouth and I made them known;/_then suddenly I did them and they came to pass.

18619.text: /Because I know that you are obstinate,/_and your neck is an iron sinew/_and your forehead brass,

18620.text: /I declared them to you from of old,/_before they came to pass I announced them to you,/lest you should say, ‘My idol did them,/_my graven image and my molten image commanded them.’

18621.text: ¶“You have heard; now see all this;/_and will you not declare it?/From this time forth I make you hear new things,/_hidden things which you have not known.

18622.text: /They are created now, not long ago;/_before today you have never heard of them,/_lest you should say, ‘Behold, I knew them.’

18623.text: /You have never heard, you have never known,/_from of old your ear has not been opened./For I knew that you would deal very treacherously,/_and that from birth you were called a rebel.

18624.text: ¶“For my name’s sake I defer my anger,/_for the sake of my praise I restrain it for you,/_that I may not cut you off.

18625.text: /Behold, I have refined you, but not like silver;/_I have tried you in the furnace of affliction.

18626.text: /For my own sake, for my own sake, I do it,/_for how should my name be profaned?/_My glory I will not give to another.

18627.text: ¶“Hearken to me, O Jacob,/_and Israel, whom I called!/I am He, I am the first,/_and I am the last.

18628.text: /My hand laid the foundation of the earth,/_and my right hand spread out the heavens;/when I call to them,/_they stand forth together.

18629.text: ¶“Assemble, all of you, and hear!/_who among them has declared these things?/The Lord loves him;/_he shall perform his purpose on Babylon,/_and his arm shall be against the Chalde′ans.

18630.text: /I, even I, have spoken and called him,/_I have brought him, and he will prosper in his way.

18631.text: /Draw near to me, hear this:/_from the beginning I have not spoken in secret,/_from the time it came to be I have been there.”/And now the Lord God has sent me and his Spirit.

18632.text: ¶Thus says the Lord,/_your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel:/“I am the Lord your God,/_who teaches you to profit,/_who leads you in the way you should go.

18633.text: /O that you had hearkened to my commandments!/_Then your peace would have been like a river,/_and your righteousness like the waves of the sea;

18634.text: /your offspring would have been like the sand,/_and your descendants like its grains;/their name would never be cut off/_or destroyed from before me.”

18635.text: ¶Go forth from Babylon, flee from Chalde′a,/_declare this with a shout of joy, proclaim it,/send it forth to the end of the earth;/_say, “The Lord has redeemed his servant Jacob!”

18636.text: /They thirsted not when he led them through the deserts;/_he made water flow for them from the rock;/_he cleft the rock and the water gushed out.

18637.text: /“There is no peace,” says the Lord, “for the wicked.”

18638.text: §¶Listen to me, O coastlands,/and hearken, you peoples from afar./The Lord called me from the womb,/_from the body of my mother he named my name.

18639.text: /He made my mouth like a sharp sword,/_in the shadow of his hand he hid me;/he made me a polished arrow,/_in his quiver he hid me away.

18640.text: /And he said to me, “You are my servant,/_Israel, in whom I will be glorified.”

18641.text: /But I said, “I have labored in vain,/_I have spent my strength for nothing and vanity;/yet surely my right is with the Lord,/_and my recompense with my God.”

18642.text: ¶And now the Lord says,/_who formed me from the womb to be his servant,/to bring Jacob back to him,/_and that Israel might be gathered to him,/for I am honored in the eyes of the Lord,/_and my God has become my strength—

18643.text: /he says:/“It is too light a thing that you should be my servant/_to raise up the tribes of Jacob/_and to restore the preserved of Israel;/I will give you as a light to the nations,/_that my salvation may reach to the end of the earth.”

18644.text: ¶Thus says the Lord,/_the Redeemer of Israel and his Holy One,/to one deeply despised, abhorred by the nations,/_the servant of rulers:/“Kings shall see and arise;/_princes, and they shall prostrate themselves;/because of the Lord, who is faithful,/_the Holy One of Israel, who has chosen you.”

18645.text: §¶Thus says the Lord:/“In a time of favor I have answered you,/_in a day of salvation I have helped you;/I have kept you and given you/_as a covenant to the people,/to establish the land,/_to apportion the desolate heritages;

18646.text: /saying to the prisoners, ‘Come forth,’/_to those who are in darkness, ‘Appear.’/They shall feed along the ways,/_on all bare heights shall be their pasture;

18647.text: /they shall not hunger or thirst,/_neither scorching wind nor sun shall smite them,/for he who has pity on them will lead them,/_and by springs of water will guide them.

18648.text: /And I will make all my mountains a way,/_and my highways shall be raised up.

18649.text: /Lo, these shall come from afar,/_and lo, these from the north and from the west,/_and these from the land of Syene.”

18650.text: /Sing for joy, O heavens, and exult, O earth;/_break forth, O mountains, into singing!/For the Lord has comforted his people,/_and will have compassion on his afflicted.

18651.text: ¶But Zion said, “The Lord has forsaken me,/_my Lord has forgotten me.”

18652.text: /“Can a woman forget her sucking child,/_that she should have no compassion on the son of her womb?/Even these may forget,/_yet I will not forget you.

18653.text: /Behold, I have graven you on the palms of my hands;/_your walls are continually before me.

18654.text: /Your builders outstrip your destroyers,/_and those who laid you waste go forth from you.

18655.text: /Lift up your eyes round about and see;/_they all gather, they come to you./As I live, says the Lord,/_you shall put them all on as an ornament,/_you shall bind them on as a bride does.

18656.text: ¶“Surely your waste and your desolate places/_and your devastated land—/surely now you will be too narrow for your inhabitants,/_and those who swallowed you up will be far away.

18657.text: /The children born in the time of your bereavement/_will yet say in your ears:/‘The place is too narrow for me;/_make room for me to dwell in.’

18658.text: /Then you will say in your heart:/_‘Who has borne me these?/I was bereaved and barren,/_exiled and put away,/_but who has brought up these?/Behold, I was left alone;/_whence then have these come?’”

18659.text: ¶Thus says the Lord God:/“Behold, I will lift up my hand to the nations,/_and raise my signal to the peoples;/and they shall bring your sons in their bosom,/_and your daughters shall be carried on their shoulders.

18660.text: /Kings shall be your foster fathers,/_and their queens your nursing mothers./With their faces to the ground they shall bow down to you,/_and lick the dust of your feet./Then you will know that I am the Lord;/_those who wait for me shall not be put to shame.”

18661.text: ¶Can the prey be taken from the mighty,/_or the captives of a tyrant be rescued?

18662.text: /Surely, thus says the Lord:/“Even the captives of the mighty shall be taken,/_and the prey of the tyrant be rescued,/for I will contend with those who contend with you,/_and I will save your children.

18663.text: /I will make your oppressors eat their own flesh,/_and they shall be drunk with their own blood as with wine./Then all flesh shall know/_that I am the Lord your Savior,/_and your Redeemer, the Mighty One of Jacob.”

18664.text: ¶Thus says the Lord:/“Where is your mother’s bill of divorce,/_with which I put her away?/Or which of my creditors is it/_to whom I have sold you?/Behold, for your iniquities you were sold,/_and for your transgressions your mother was put away.

18665.text: /Why, when I came, was there no man?/_When I called, was there no one to answer?/Is my hand shortened, that it cannot redeem?/_Or have I no power to deliver?/Behold, by my rebuke I dry up the sea,/_I make the rivers a desert;/their fish stink for lack of water,/_and die of thirst.

18666.text: /I clothe the heavens with blackness,/_and make sackcloth their covering.”

18667.text: §¶The Lord God has given me/_the tongue of those who are taught,/that I may know how to sustain with a word/_him that is weary./Morning by morning he wakens,/_he wakens my ear/_to hear as those who are taught.

18668.text: /The Lord God has opened my ear,/_and I was not rebellious,/_I turned not backward.

18669.text: /I gave my back to the smiters,/_and my cheeks to those who pulled out the beard;/I hid not my face/_from shame and spitting.

18670.text: ¶For the Lord God helps me;/_therefore I have not been confounded;/therefore I have set my face like a flint,/_and I know that I shall not be put to shame;

18671.text: /_he who vindicates me is near./Who will contend with me?/_Let us stand up together./Who is my adversary?/_Let him come near to me.

18672.text: /Behold, the Lord God helps me;/_who will declare me guilty?/Behold, all of them will wear out like a garment;/_the moth will eat them up.

18673.text: ¶Who among you fears the Lord/_and obeys the voice of his servant,/who walks in darkness/_and has no light,/yet trusts in the name of the Lord/_and relies upon his God?

18674.text: /Behold, all you who kindle a fire,/_who set brands alight!/Walk by the light of your fire,/_and by the brands which you have kindled!/This shall you have from my hand:/_you shall lie down in torment.

18675.text: §¶“Hearken to me, you who pursue deliverance,/_you who seek the Lord;/look to the rock from which you were hewn,/_and to the quarry from which you were digged.

18676.text: /Look to Abraham your father/_and to Sarah who bore you;/for when he was but one I called him,/_and I blessed him and made him many.

18677.text: /For the Lord will comfort Zion;/_he will comfort all her waste places,/and will make her wilderness like Eden,/_her desert like the garden of the Lord;/joy and gladness will be found in her,/_thanksgiving and the voice of song.

18678.text: ¶“Listen to me, my people,/_and give ear to me, my nation;/for a law will go forth from me,/_and my justice for a light to the peoples.

18679.text: /My deliverance draws near speedily,/_my salvation has gone forth,/_and my arms will rule the peoples;/the coastlands wait for me,/_and for my arm they hope.

18680.text: /Lift up your eyes to the heavens,/_and look at the earth beneath;/for the heavens will vanish like smoke,/_the earth will wear out like a garment,/_and they who dwell in it will die like gnats;/but my salvation will be for ever,/_and my deliverance will never be ended.

18681.text: ¶“Hearken to me, you who know righteousness,/_the people in whose heart is my law;/fear not the reproach of men,/_and be not dismayed at their revilings.

18682.text: /For the moth will eat them up like a garment,/_and the worm will eat them like wool;/but my deliverance will be for ever,/_and my salvation to all generations.”

18683.text: ¶Awake, awake, put on strength,/_O arm of the Lord;/awake, as in days of old,/_the generations of long ago./Was it not thou that didst cut Rahab in pieces,/_that didst pierce the dragon?

18684.text: /Was it not thou that didst dry up the sea,/_the waters of the great deep;/that didst make the depths of the sea a way/_for the redeemed to pass over?

18685.text: /And the ransomed of the Lord shall return,/_and come to Zion with singing;/everlasting joy shall be upon their heads;/_they shall obtain joy and gladness,/_and sorrow and sighing shall flee away.

18686.text: ¶“I, I am he that comforts you;/_who are you that you are afraid of man who dies,/_of the son of man who is made like grass,

18687.text: /and have forgotten the Lord, your Maker,/_who stretched out the heavens/_and laid the foundations of the earth,/and fear continually all the day/_because of the fury of the oppressor,/when he sets himself to destroy?/_And where is the fury of the oppressor?

18688.text: /He who is bowed down shall speedily be released;/_he shall not die and go down to the Pit,/_neither shall his bread fail.

18689.text: /For I am the Lord your God,/_who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar—/_the Lord of hosts is his name.

18690.text: /And I have put my words in your mouth,/_and hid you in the shadow of my hand,/stretching out the heavens/_and laying the foundations of the earth,/_and saying to Zion, ‘You are my people.’”

18691.text: ¶Rouse yourself, rouse yourself,/_stand up, O Jerusalem,/you who have drunk at the hand of the Lord/_the cup of his wrath,/who have drunk to the dregs/_the bowl of staggering.

18692.text: /There is none to guide her/_among all the sons she has borne;/there is none to take her by the hand/_among all the sons she has brought up.

18693.text: /These two things have befallen you—/_who will condole with you?—/devastation and destruction, famine and sword;/_who will comfort you?

18694.text: /Your sons have fainted,/_they lie at the head of every street/_like an antelope in a net;/they are full of the wrath of the Lord,/_the rebuke of your God.

18695.text: ¶Therefore hear this, you who are afflicted,/_who are drunk, but not with wine:

18696.text: /Thus says your Lord, the Lord,/_your God who pleads the cause of his people:/“Behold, I have taken from your hand/_the cup of staggering;/the bowl of my wrath/_you shall drink no more;
